The United States Space Force's Space Launch Delta 30 serves as the host delta for the base, equivalent to an Air Force air base wing. In addition to its military space launch mission, Vandenberg Space Force Base also hosts space launches for civil and commercial space entities, such as NASA and SpaceX.",

                                  "description": "Electron is a two-stage orbital expendable launch vehicle (with an optional third stage) developed by the American aerospace company Rocket Lab. Electron is a small-lift launch vehicle designed to launch small satellites and cubesats to sun-synchronous orbit and low earth orbit. The Electron is the first orbital class rocket to use electric-pump-fed engines, powered by the 9 Rutherford engines on the first stage. class=\"penci-mega-date\"><time class=\"entry-date published\" datetime=\"2023-04-26T21:27:44-05:00\">April 26, 2023</time></p>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                                    </div>\n                                </div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                    </div>\n\t\t\t\t\t                    <div class=\"penci-mega-row penci-mega-14\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t                                <div class=\"penci-mega-post\">\n                                    <div class=\"penci-mega-thumbnail\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                                            <span class=\"penci-image-holder penci-lazy\" data-bgset=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/IMG_6688-263x175.jpeg\" href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2025/11/sentinel-6b-falcon-9/\" title=\"Sentinel-6B ocean monitoring satellite launches aboard Falcon 9\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                                            </a>\n                                    </div>\n                                    <div class=\"penci-mega-meta\">\n launches aboard Falcon 9\">Sentinel-6B ocean monitoring satellite launches aboard Falcon 9</a>\n                                        </h3>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/news/other/unmanned/\">Uncrewed</a>\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                                        <a class=\"penci-image-holder penci-lazy\" data-bgset=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/NSF-2025-08-20-18-14-08-653-263x175.jpg\" href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2025/08/russia-bion-m/\" title=\"Russia launches Bion-M No.2 research satellite\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t satellite\">Russia launches Bion-M No.2 research satellite</a>\n                                        </h3>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                                            <p menu-item-96018\"><a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/schedule/\">Schedule</a></li>\n</ul>        </nav>\n    </div>\n    </div>\n</div>\n    </div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"penci-single-wrapper\" style=\"transform: none; height: auto !important;\">\n    <div class=\"penci-single-block\" style=\"transform: none; height: auto !important;\">\n\t\t\n\t\t\n        <div class=\"container container-single container-single-magazine penci_sidebar  penci-enable-lightbox\" style=\"transform: none; height: auto !important;\">\n            <div id=\"main\" class=\"penci-main-sticky-sidebar\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: visible; box-sizing: border-box; min-height: 0px !important; height: auto !important;\">\n                <div class=\"theiaStickySidebar\" style=\"padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 1px; position: static; height: auto !important;\">\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<article id=\"post-112148\" class=\"post type-post status-publish\" style=\"height: auto !important;\">\n\n\t\n\t\t\n            <div class=\"header-standard header-classic single-header\">\n\t            \t\t\t\t\n\n                <h1 class=\"post-title single-post-title entry-title\">NASA prepares for likely rollback of SLS, delaying Artemis II to April</h1>\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"penci-hide-tagupdated\">\n\t\t\t<span class=\"author-italic author vcard\">by                                         <a class=\"author-url url fn n\" href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/author/chrisbergin/\">Chris Bergin</a>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</span>\n\t\t\t<time class=\"entry-date published\" datetime=\"2026-02-21T15:45:33-05:00\">February 21, 2026</time>\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                    <div class=\"post-box-meta-single\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t                            <span class=\"author-post byline\"><span class=\"author vcard\">written by                                         <a class=\"author-url url fn n\" href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/author/chrisbergin/\">Chris Bergin</a>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</span></span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                            <span><time class=\"entry-date published\" datetime=\"2026-02-21T15:45:33-05:00\">February 21, 2026</time></span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                    </div>\n\t\t\t\t\t                        </div>\n\n\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\n\t\t\n\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                    <div class=\"post-image\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-33-45-477-wmarked.jpg\" data-rel=\"penci-gallery-image-content\">\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                                <img class=\"attachment-penci-full-thumb size-penci-full-thumb penci-lazy wp-post-image pc-singlep-img lazyloaded pcloaded\" width=\"1568\" height=\"1118\" src=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-33-45-477-wmarked.jpg\" alt=\"\" title=\"NSF 2026-02-21 20-33-45-477-wmarked\" data-sizes=\"auto\" data-srcset=\"\" data-src=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-33-45-477-wmarked.jpg\" data-ll-status=\"loaded\" sizes=\"auto\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</a>                    </div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\t    <div class=\"post-entry blockquote-style-2\" style=\"height: auto !important;\">\n        <div class=\"inner-post-entry entry-content\" id=\"penci-post-entry-inner\" style=\"height: auto !important;\">\n\n\t\t\t<i class=\"penci-post-countview-number-check\" style=\"display:none\">178</i>\n\t\t\t<p>NASA is gearing up for a likely rollback of the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket and Orion spacecraft to the Vehicle Assembly Building (VAB) at Kennedy Space Center in Florida.</p>\n<p>The decision follows an unexpected interruption in helium flow within the rocket’s interim cryogenic propulsion stage (ICPS), observed overnight on Saturday, February 21, 2026.<br>\n<span id=\"more-112148\"></span></p>\n<p><div class=\"fluid-width-video-wrapper\" style=\"padding-top: 56.2393%;\"><iframe title=\"What Broke on Artemis II? Helium System Fault After Perfect Rehearsal\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/dTxQMz4l5ZI?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\" referrerpolicy=\"strict-origin-when-cross-origin\" allowfullscreen=\"\" name=\"fitvid0\" data-gtm-yt-inspected-12=\"true\" data-gtm-yt-inspected-17=\"true\"></iframe></div></p>\n<p>This issue with the ICPS has prompted teams to review data and prepare contingency measures, effectively ruling out the targeted March launch window and pushing the mission toward a possible April liftoff if the rollback is confirmed.</p>\n<p>Pre-rollback work is already underway, including the removal of pad access platforms installed yesterday. These platforms are subject to wind constraints and cannot be removed during high winds, which are forecasted for tomorrow.</p>\n<div class=\"twitter-tweet twitter-tweet-rendered\" style=\"display: flex; max-width: 550px; width: 100%; margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px;\"><iframe id=\"twitter-widget-1\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" allowtransparency=\"true\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" class=\"\" title=\"X Post\" src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/embed/Tweet.html?creatorScreenName=NASASpaceflight&amp;dnt=true&amp;embedId=twitter-widget-1&amp;%3D%3D&amp;frame=false&amp;hideCard=false&amp;hideThread=false&amp;id=2025301712509051375&amp;lang=en&amp;origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nasaspaceflight.com%2F2026%2F02%2Fnasa-rollback-sls-delaying-artemis-april%2F&amp;sessionId=3806382b60558237ae434d7008f6d08cc3488347&amp;siteScreenName=NASASpaceflight&amp;theme=light&amp;widgetsVersion=2615f7e52b7e0%3A1702314776716&amp;width=550px\" style=\"position: static; visibility: visible; width: 550px; height: 648px; display: block; flex-grow: 1;\" data-gtm-yt-inspected-12=\"true\" data-gtm-yt-inspected-17=\"true\" data-tweet-id=\"2025301712509051375\"></iframe></div>\n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p>\n<p>Following a successful second Wet Dress Rehearsal (WDR), NASA took the unusual step of announcing a target launch date of March 6 for Artemis II—despite traditionally waiting until the completion of the Flight Readiness Review (FRR) to set firm dates.</p>\n<p>Less than 24 hours later, that date became non-viable after an overnight helium flow anomaly was noted.</p>\n<div><div class=\"penci-custom-html-inside-content\"><script async=\"\" src=\"https://pagead2.googlesyndication.com/pagead/js/adsbygoogle.js?client=ca-pub-2638787791243800\" crossorigin=\"anonymous\" data-checked-head=\"true\"></script>\n<ins class=\"adsbygoogle\" style=\"display: block; text-align: center; height: auto !important; background-color: transparent !important;\" data-ad-layout=\"in-article\" data-ad-format=\"fluid\" data-ad-client=\"ca-pub-2638787791243800\" data-ad-slot=\"9172026781\" data-adsbygoogle-status=\"done\" data-ad-status=\"unfill-optimized\"><div id=\"aswift_1_host\" style=\"border: none; height: auto !important; width: 726px; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; position: relative; visibility: visible; background-color: transparent; display: inline-block; overflow: visible;\"><div data-google-ad-efd=\"true\" class=\"google-aiuf\" style=\"width: 726px !important; display: flex !important; flex-wrap: wrap !important; place-content: center !important; align-items: center !important; gap: 10px !important; font-size: initial !important; height: auto !important; max-height: 280px !important;\"><div class=\"goog-rentries\" style=\"animation-delay: 0s !important; text-shadow: none !important; text-size-adjust: auto !important; text-overflow: clip !important; text-transform: none !important; touch-action: auto !important; transition-delay: 0s !important; transition-duration: 0s !important; transition-property: all !important; transition-timing-function: ease !important; unicode-bidi: normal !important; vertical-align: baseline !important; visibility: inherit !important; white-space: normal !important; widows: 2 !important; width: 100% !important; will-change: auto !important; word-break: normal !important; word-spacing: 0px !important; z-index: auto !important; zoom: 1 !important; appearance: none !important; backface-visibility: visible !important; border-spacing: 0px !important; -webkit-border-image: none !important; -webkit-box-align: stretch !important; -webkit-box-decoration-break: slice !important; -webkit-box-direction: normal !important; -webkit-box-flex: 0 !important; -webkit-box-ordinal-group: 1 !important; -webkit-box-orient: horizontal !important; -webkit-box-pack: start !important; column-count: auto !important; gap: normal !important; column-rule: 0px rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; column-span: none !important; column-width: auto !important; backdrop-filter: none !important; place-content: normal !important; flex: 0 1 auto !important; flex-flow: row !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: auto !important; grid: none !important; grid-area: auto !important; hyphens: manual !important; hyphenate-character: auto !important; -webkit-line-break: auto !important; -webkit-line-clamp: none !important; -webkit-locale: auto !important; -webkit-mask-box-image-source: none !important; -webkit-mask-box-image-slice: 0 fill !important; -webkit-mask-box-image-width: auto !important; -webkit-mask-box-image-outset: 0px !important; -webkit-mask-box-image-repeat: stretch !important; mask: none !important; order: 0 !important; perspective: none !important; perspective-origin: 0px 0px !important; print-color-adjust: economy !important; -webkit-rtl-ordering: logical !important; shape-outside: none !important; shape-image-threshold: 0 !important; shape-margin: 0px !important; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4) !important; -webkit-text-combine: none !important; -webkit-text-decorations-in-effect: none !important; text-emphasis: none rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; text-emphasis-position: over right !important; -webkit-text-orientation: vertical-right !important; -webkit-text-security: none !important; -webkit-text-stroke: 0px rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; transform: none !important; transform-origin: 0px 0px !important; transform-style: flat !important; -webkit-user-drag: auto !important; -webkit-user-modify: read-only !important; user-select: auto !important; -webkit-writing-mode: horizontal-tb !important; app-region: none !important; buffered-rendering: auto !important; clip-path: none !important; clip-rule: nonzero !important; filter: none !important; flood-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; flood-opacity: 1 !important; lighting-color: rgb(255, 255, 255) !important; stop-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; stop-opacity: 1 !important; color-interpolation: srgb !important; color-interpolation-filters: linearrgb !important; color-rendering: auto !important; fill: rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; fill-opacity: 1 !important; fill-rule: nonzero !important; marker: none !important; mask-type: luminance !important; shape-rendering: auto !important; stroke: none !important; stroke-dasharray: none !important; stroke-dashoffset: 0px !important; stroke-linecap: butt !important; stroke-linejoin: miter !important; stroke-miterlimit: 4 !important; stroke-opacity: 1 !important; stroke-width: 1px !important; alignment-baseline: auto !important; baseline-shift: 0px !important; dominant-baseline: auto !important; text-anchor: start !important; writing-mode: inherit !important; vector-effect: none !important; paint-order: normal !important; d: none !important; cx: 0px !important; cy: 0px !important; x: 0px !important; y: 0px !important; r: 0px !important; rx: auto !important; ry: auto !important; caret-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; line-break: auto !important; text-orientation: inherit !important;\"></div></div></div></div></ins>\n<script>\n     (adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({});\n</script></div></div><p>NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman addressed the development in a statement, emphasizing the troubleshooting efforts underway.</p>\n<p>“After overnight data showed an interruption in helium flow in the SLS interim cryogenic propulsion stage, teams are troubleshooting and preparing for a likely rollback of Artemis II to the VAB,” Isaacman said. “This will almost assuredly impact the March launch window.”</p>\n<p>Notably, NSF was hearing rumors of a potential vehicle issue that could result in a rollback on Saturday morning. Less than an hour later, NASA and Isaacman published a statement online—an impressive sign of the Administrator’s commitment to increasing transparency at the agency.</p>\n<div class=\"twitter-tweet twitter-tweet-rendered\" style=\"display: flex; max-width: 550px; width: 100%; margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px;\"><iframe id=\"twitter-widget-2\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" allowtransparency=\"true\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" class=\"\" title=\"X Post\" src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/embed/Tweet.html?creatorScreenName=NASASpaceflight&amp;dnt=true&amp;embedId=twitter-widget-2&amp;%3D%3D&amp;frame=false&amp;hideCard=false&amp;hideThread=false&amp;id=2025249086908125630&amp;lang=en&amp;origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nasaspaceflight.com%2F2026%2F02%2Fnasa-rollback-sls-delaying-artemis-april%2F&amp;sessionId=3806382b60558237ae434d7008f6d08cc3488347&amp;siteScreenName=NASASpaceflight&amp;theme=light&amp;widgetsVersion=2615f7e52b7e0%3A1702314776716&amp;width=550px\" style=\"position: static; visibility: visible; width: 550px; height: 537px; display: block; flex-grow: 1;\" data-gtm-yt-inspected-12=\"true\" data-gtm-yt-inspected-17=\"true\" data-tweet-id=\"2025249086908125630\"></iframe></div>\n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p>\n<p>The ICPS, or Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage, is effectively the SLS rocket’s upper stage.</p>\n<p>Derived from the Delta IV rocket’s second stage and adapted for Artemis missions, it uses liquid hydrogen (LH2) and liquid oxygen (LOX) as propellants to provide the necessary thrust after core stage burnout, enabling the Orion spacecraft to reach lunar orbit insertion trajectories.<br>\n<img fetchpriority=\"high\" decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-112151\" src=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1170\" height=\"778\" srcset=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1.jpg 1170w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-350x233.jpg 350w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-526x350.jpg 526w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-768x511.jpg 768w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-585x390.jpg 585w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-263x175.jpg 263w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1170px) 100vw, 1170px\">Helium plays a vital role in this system. Stored in onboard bottles, it purges the engines of residual gases and pressurizes the LH2 and LOX tanks during ascent.</p>\n<p>According to Isaacman, the ICPS helium system performed flawlessly during the first two Wet Dress Rehearsals (WDRs), which are full-scale fueling simulations conducted at Launch Pad 39B. The second WDR, in particular, proceeded according to plan with no indications of helium issues.</p>\n<p>“The ICPS helium bottles are used to purge the engines, as well as for LH2 and LOX tank pressurization. The systems did work correctly during WDR1 and WDR2,” he noted.</p>\n<p><div class=\"fluid-width-video-wrapper\" style=\"padding-top: 56.2393%;\"><iframe title=\"NASA conducts Second Wet Dress Rehearsal on SLS ahead of Artemis II (Part II)\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/WRt0i4_3N7k?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\" referrerpolicy=\"strict-origin-when-cross-origin\" allowfullscreen=\"\" name=\"fitvid1\" data-gtm-yt-inspected-12=\"true\" data-gtm-yt-inspected-17=\"true\"></iframe></div></p>\n<p>The problem emerged during a routine repressurization operation last evening, catching teams off guard.</p>\n<p>“This was an unexpected development during routine helium flow operations last evening. The teams were up all night assessing the situation,” Isaacman added.</p>\n<p>Engineers are investigating potential causes, drawing parallels to a similar failure signature encountered during the Artemis I uncrewed mission in 2022.</p>\n<p>Possible faults include a final filter on the umbilical connection between ground systems and the vehicle, a failed quick-disconnect (QD) umbilical interface—where issues have been noted before—or a malfunctioning check valve onboard the rocket.</p>\n<p>Corrective measures were implemented post-Artemis I to reduce such risks for Artemis II, but the recurrence underscores the challenges of cryogenic systems in extreme environments.</p>\n<p>Isaacman also explained why a rollback is likely: remediation for any of these issues requires access only available in the VAB, which features numerous platform levels that rotate into place around the stack.<br>\n<img decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-112152\" src=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1560\" height=\"885\" srcset=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916.jpg 1560w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-350x199.jpg 350w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-617x350.jpg 617w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-768x436.jpg 768w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-1170x664.jpg 1170w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1560px) 100vw, 1560px\">“Regardless of the potential fault, accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB,” he confirmed.</p>\n<aside class=\"penci-sidebar-content widget l2-info\"><h4 class=\"widget-title penci-border-arrow\"><span class=\"inner-arrow\">See Also</span></h4><ul><li><a href=\"https://forum.nasaspaceflight.com/index.php?board=48.0\">Artemis Section</a></li><li><a href=\"https://forum.nasaspaceflight.com/index.php?board=37.0\">L2 Artemis</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/l2/\">Click here to Join L2</a></li></ul></aside>\n<p>The vehicle remains in a safe configuration, relying on ground-based environmental control systems (ECS) for engine purging instead of the onboard helium supply.</p>\n<p>This potential rollback echoes delays in previous Artemis preparations, where weather, technical glitches, and supply chain issues have repeatedly extended timelines. The March window, already tight, now appears off the table, with April emerging as the next viable opportunity—assuming swift resolution.</p>\n<p>“A rollback would mean NASA will not launch Artemis II in the March launch window,” NASA noted. “However, the quick preparations enable NASA to potentially preserve the April launch window if a rollback is required, pending the outcome of data findings, repair efforts, and how the schedule comes to fruition in the coming days and weeks.”</p>\n<p>NASA is set to provide another update during the coming week, which will also address requirements for a rollback, including resolution and return to the pad.</p>\n<p>The latter may require at least a tanking test or mini-WDR to confirm that the trip up and down the crawlerway did not affect systems such as the LH2 tail service mast umbilical (TSMU), which necessitated WDR2.</p>\n<p><em>Lead photo: Tyler Gray for NSF.</em></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://shop.nasaspaceflight.com/pages/artemis-ii\"><img decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignnone wp-image-111837 size-full\" src=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1665\" height=\"891\" srcset=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276.jpg 1665w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-350x187.jpg 350w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-630x337.jpg 630w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-768x411.jpg 768w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-1170x626.jpg 1170w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1665px) 100vw, 1665px\"></a></p>\n\n\t\t\t\n            <div class=\"penci-single-link-pages\">\n\t\t\t\t            </div>\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                    <div class=\"post-tags\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/tag/39b/\" rel=\"tag\">39B</a><a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/tag/artemis/\" rel=\"tag\">Artemis</a><a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/tag/icps/\" rel=\"tag\">ICPS</a><a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/tag/orion/\" rel=\"tag\">Orion</a><a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/tag/sls/\" rel=\"tag\">SLS</a>                    </div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2026/02/launch-preview-020926/\">Launch Preview: Vulcan launches USSF-87, SpaceX sends Crew-12...</a>\n                        </h3>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t class=\"owl-item cloned\" style=\"width: 363px;\"><div class=\"item-related\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                        <a class=\"related-thumb penci-image-holder\" style=\"background-image:     </a>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t                        <h3>\n                            <a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2026/02/starbases-launch-site-double-size/\">Starbase’s launch site lays groundwork to double in...</a>\n                        </h3>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t                            <span class=\"date\"><time class=\"entry-date published\" datetime=\"2026-02-07T14:57:50-05:00\">February 7, 2026</time></span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t                </div></div><div class=\"owl-item active\" style=\"width: 363px;\"><div type=\"speculationrules\">\n{\"prefetch\":[{\"source\":\"document\",\"where\":{\"and\":[{\"href_matches\":\"\\/*\"},{\"not\":{\"href_matches\":[\"\\/wp-*.php\",\"\\/wp-admin\\/*\",\"\\/wp-content\\/uploads\\/*\",\"\\/wp-content\\/*\",\"\\/wp-content\\/plugins\\/*\",\"\\/wp-content\\/themes\\/soledad-nsf\\/*\",\"\\/wp-content\\/themes\\/soledad\\/*\",\"\\/*\\\\?(.+)\"]}},{\"not\":{\"selector_matches\":\"a[rel~=\\\"nofollow\\\"]\"}},{\"not\":{\"selector_matches\":\".no-prefetch, .no-prefetch a\"}}]},\"eagerness\":\"conservative\"}]}\n</script>\n<script id=\"penci-dm-checking\" type=\"text/javascript\">function penci_dmgetcookie(cname) {\n    let name = cname + \"=\";\n    let decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);\n    let ca = decodedCookie.split(';');\n    for (let i = 0; i < ca.length; i++) {\n        let c = ca[i];\n        while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {\n            c = c.substring(1);\n        }\n        if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {\n            return c.substring(name.length, c.length);\n        }\n    }\n    return \"\";\n}\n\nlet alllogos = document.querySelectorAll('.penci-limg'),\n    body = document.querySelector('body'),\n    autoby = penci_dark.auto_by,\n    darktheme = penci_dark.darktheme,\n    hr = (new Date()).getHours(),\n                 "startTime": 1771765261786,

                  "main": [
                    [
                      {
                        "json": {
                          "title": "NASA prepares for likely rollback of SLS, delaying Artemis II to April",
                          "url": "https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2026/02/nasa-rollback-sls-delaying-artemis-april/",
                          "date": "February 21, 2026",
                          "thumbnail": "https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-33-45-477-wmarked.jpg",
                          "images": [
                            "https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1.jpg",
                            "https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916.jpg",
                            "https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276.jpg"
                          ],
                          "source": "NASASpaceFlight.com",
                          "content": "NASA is gearing up for a likely rollback of the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket and Orion spacecraft to the Vehicle Assembly Building (VAB) at Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The decision follows an unexpected interruption in helium flow within the rocket’s interim cryogenic propulsion stage (ICPS), observed overnight on Saturday, February 21, 2026. This issue with the ICPS has prompted teams to review data and prepare contingency measures, effectively ruling out the targeted March launch window and pushing the mission toward a possible April liftoff if the rollback is confirmed. Pre-rollback work is already underway, including the removal of pad access platforms installed yesterday. These platforms are subject to wind constraints and cannot be removed during high winds, which are forecasted for tomorrow. Following a successful second Wet Dress Rehearsal (WDR), NASA took the unusual step of announcing a target launch date of March 6 for Artemis II—despite traditionally waiting until the completion of the Flight Readiness Review (FRR) to set firm dates. Less than 24 hours later, that date became non-viable after an overnight helium flow anomaly was noted. Discover more NASA merchandise Chinese spaceflight analysis Space exploration books NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman addressed the development in a statement, emphasizing the troubleshooting efforts underway. “After overnight data showed an interruption in helium flow in the SLS interim cryogenic propulsion stage, teams are troubleshooting and preparing for a likely rollback of Artemis II to the VAB,” Isaacman said. “This will almost assuredly impact the March launch window.” Notably, NSF was hearing rumors of a potential vehicle issue that could result in a rollback on Saturday morning. Less than an hour later, NASA and Isaacman published a statement online—an impressive sign of the Administrator’s commitment to increasing transparency at the agency. The ICPS, or Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage, is effectively the SLS rocket’s upper stage. Derived from the Delta IV rocket’s second stage and adapted for Artemis missions, it uses liquid hydrogen (LH2) and liquid oxygen (LOX) as propellants to provide the necessary thrust after core stage burnout, enabling the Orion spacecraft to reach lunar orbit insertion trajectories. Helium plays a vital role in this system. Stored in onboard bottles, it purges the engines of residual gases and pressurizes the LH2 and LOX tanks during ascent. According to Isaacman, the ICPS helium system performed flawlessly during the first two Wet Dress Rehearsals (WDRs), which are full-scale fueling simulations conducted at Launch Pad 39B. The second WDR, in particular, proceeded according to plan with no indications of helium issues. “The ICPS helium bottles are used to purge the engines, as well as for LH2 and LOX tank pressurization. The systems did work correctly during WDR1 and WDR2,” he noted. The problem emerged during a routine repressurization operation last evening, catching teams off guard. “This was an unexpected development during routine helium flow operations last evening. The teams were up all night assessing the situation,” Isaacman added. Engineers are investigating potential causes, drawing parallels to a similar failure signature encountered during the Artemis I uncrewed mission in 2022. Possible faults include a final filter on the umbilical connection between ground systems and the vehicle, a failed quick-disconnect (QD) umbilical interface—where issues have been noted before—or a malfunctioning check valve onboard the rocket. Corrective measures were implemented post-Artemis I to reduce such risks for Artemis II, but the recurrence underscores the challenges of cryogenic systems in extreme environments. Isaacman also explained why a rollback is likely: remediation for any of these issues requires access only available in the VAB, which features numerous platform levels that rotate into place around the stack. “Regardless of the potential fault, accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB,” he confirmed. See Also Artemis Section L2 Artemis Click here to Join L2 The vehicle remains in a safe configuration, relying on ground-based environmental control systems (ECS) for engine purging instead of the onboard helium supply. This potential rollback echoes delays in previous Artemis preparations, where weather, technical glitches, and supply chain issues have repeatedly extended timelines. The March window, already tight, now appears off the table, with April emerging as the next viable opportunity—assuming swift resolution. “A rollback would mean NASA will not launch Artemis II in the March launch window,” NASA noted. “However, the quick preparations enable NASA to potentially preserve the April launch window if a rollback is required, pending the outcome of data findings, repair efforts, and how the schedule comes to fruition in the coming days and weeks.” NASA is set to provide another update during the coming week, which will also address requirements for a rollback, including resolution and return to the pad. The latter may require at least a tanking test or mini-WDR to confirm that the trip up and down the crawlerway did not affect systems such as the LH2 tail service mast umbilical (TSMU), which necessitated WDR2. Lead photo: Tyler Gray for NSF. 39B Artemis ICPS Orion SLS 0 Facebook Twitter Pinterest Email previous article Boeing insists NASA criticism will reinforce efforts on Starliner Related Articles 39A CAA removed, ending crew launch from historic... stroke-linecap: butt !important; stroke-linejoin: miter !important; stroke-miterlimit: 4 !important; stroke-opacity: 1 !important; stroke-width: 1px !important; alignment-baseline: auto !important; baseline-shift: 0px !important; dominant-baseline: auto !important; text-anchor: start !important; writing-mode: inherit !important; vector-effect: none !important; paint-order: normal !important; d: none !important; cx: 0px !important; cy: 0px !important; x: 0px !important; y: 0px !important; r: 0px !important; rx: auto !important; ry: auto !important; caret-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; line-break: auto !important; text-orientation: inherit !important;\"></div></div></div></div></ins>\n<script>\n     (adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({});\n</script></div></div><p>NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman addressed the development in a statement, emphasizing the troubleshooting efforts underway.</p>\n<p>“After overnight data showed an interruption in helium flow in the SLS interim cryogenic propulsion stage, teams are troubleshooting and preparing for a likely rollback of Artemis II to the VAB,” Isaacman said. “This will almost assuredly impact the March launch window.”</p>\n<p>Notably, NSF was hearing rumors of a potential vehicle issue that could result in a rollback on Saturday morning. Less than an hour later, NASA and Isaacman published a statement online—an impressive sign of the Administrator’s commitment to increasing transparency at the agency.</p>\n<div class=\"twitter-tweet twitter-tweet-rendered\" style=\"display: flex; max-width: 550px; width: 100%; margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px;\"></div>\n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p>\n<p>The ICPS, or Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage, is effectively the SLS rocket’s upper stage.</p>\n<p>Derived from the Delta IV rocket’s second stage and adapted for Artemis missions, it uses liquid hydrogen (LH2) and liquid oxygen (LOX) as propellants to provide the necessary thrust after core stage burnout, enabling the Orion spacecraft to reach lunar orbit insertion trajectories.<br>\n<img fetchpriority=\"high\" decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-112151\" src=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1170\" height=\"778\" srcset=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1.jpg 1170w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-350x233.jpg 350w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-526x350.jpg 526w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-768x511.jpg 768w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-585x390.jpg 585w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-263x175.jpg 263w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1170px) 100vw, 1170px\">Helium plays a vital role in this system. Stored in onboard bottles, it purges the engines of residual gases and pressurizes the LH2 and LOX tanks during ascent.</p>\n<p>According to Isaacman, the ICPS helium system performed flawlessly during the first two Wet Dress Rehearsals (WDRs), which are full-scale fueling simulations conducted at Launch Pad 39B. The second WDR, in particular, proceeded according to plan with no indications of helium issues.</p>\n<p>“The ICPS helium bottles are used to purge the engines, as well as for LH2 and LOX tank pressurization. The systems did work correctly during WDR1 and WDR2,” he noted.</p>\n<p></p>\n<p>The problem emerged during a routine repressurization operation last evening, catching teams off guard.</p>\n<p>“This was an unexpected development during routine helium flow operations last evening. The teams were up all night assessing the situation,” Isaacman added.</p>\n<p>Engineers are investigating potential causes, drawing parallels to a similar failure signature encountered during the Artemis I uncrewed mission in 2022.</p>\n<p>Possible faults include a final filter on the umbilical connection between ground systems and the vehicle, a failed quick-disconnect (QD) umbilical interface—where issues have been noted before—or a malfunctioning check valve onboard the rocket.</p>\n<p>Corrective measures were implemented post-Artemis I to reduce such risks for Artemis II, but the recurrence underscores the challenges of cryogenic systems in extreme environments.</p>\n<p>Isaacman also explained why a rollback is likely: remediation for any of these issues requires access only available in the VAB, which features numerous platform levels that rotate into place around the stack.<br>\n<img decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-112152\" src=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1560\" height=\"885\" srcset=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916.jpg 1560w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-350x199.jpg 350w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-617x350.jpg 617w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-768x436.jpg 768w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-1170x664.jpg 1170w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1560px) 100vw, 1560px\">“Regardless of the potential fault, accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB,” he confirmed.</p>\n<aside class=\"penci-sidebar-content widget l2-info\"><h4 class=\"widget-title penci-border-arrow\"><span class=\"inner-arrow\">See Also</span></h4><ul><li><a href=\"https://forum.nasaspaceflight.com/index.php?board=48.0\">Artemis Section</a></li><li><a href=\"https://forum.nasaspaceflight.com/index.php?board=37.0\">L2 Artemis</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/l2/\">Click here to Join L2</a></li></ul></aside>\n<p>The vehicle remains in a safe configuration, relying on ground-based environmental control systems (ECS) for engine purging instead of the onboard helium supply.</p>\n<p>This potential rollback echoes delays in previous Artemis preparations, where weather, technical glitches, and supply chain issues have repeatedly extended timelines. The March window, already tight, now appears off the table, with April emerging as the next viable opportunity—assuming swift resolution.</p>\n<p>“A rollback would mean NASA will not launch Artemis II in the March launch window,” NASA noted. “However, the quick preparations enable NASA to potentially preserve the April launch window if a rollback is required, pending the outcome of data findings, repair efforts, and how the schedule comes to fruition in the coming days and weeks.”</p>\n<p>NASA is set to provide another update during the coming week, which will also address requirements for a rollback, including resolution and return to the pad.</p>\n<p>The latter may require at least a tanking test or mini-WDR to confirm that the trip up and down the crawlerway did not affect systems such as the LH2 tail service mast umbilical (TSMU), which necessitated WDR2.</p>\n<p><em>Lead photo: Tyler Gray for NSF.</em></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://shop.nasaspaceflight.com/pages/artemis-ii\"><img decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignnone wp-image-111837 size-full\" src=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1665\" height=\"891\" srcset=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276.jpg 1665w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-350x187.jpg 350w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-630x337.jpg 630w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-768x411.jpg 768w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-1170x626.jpg 1170w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1665px) 100vw, 1665px\"></a></p>\n\n\t\t\t\n            <div class=\"penci-single-link-pages\">\n\t\t\t\t            </div>\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                    <div class=\"post-tags\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/tag/39b/\" rel=\"tag\">39B</a><a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/tag/artemis/\" rel=\"tag\">Artemis</a><a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/tag/icps/\" rel=\"tag\">ICPS</a><a              <a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2026/02/starbase-pad-2-booster-19/\">Starbase Pad 2 prepares to receive Booster 19...</a>\n                        </h3>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t                            <span class=\"date\"><time class=\"entry-date published\" datetime=\"2026-02-17T18:24:33-05:00\">February 17, 2026</time></span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t                </div></div><div class=\"owl-item\" style=\"width: 363px;\"><div class=\"item-related\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                        <a class=\"related-thumb penci-image-holder\" style=\"background-image: url('https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/IMG_2706-585x390.jpeg');\" href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2026/02/launch-preview-021626/\" title=\"Launch Preview: Firefly to launch Alpha, SpaceX to launch three Starlink missions\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                        </a>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t                        <h3>\n                            <a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2026/02/launch-preview-021626/\">Launch Preview: Firefly to launch Alpha, SpaceX to...</a>\n                        </h3>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t                            <span class=\"date\"><time class=\"entry-date published\" datetime=\"2026-02-16T18:04:49-05:00\">February 16, 2026</time></span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t                </div></div><div class=\"owl-item\" style=\"width: 363px;\"><div class=\"item-related\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                        <a class=\"related-thumb penci-image-holder\" style=\"background-image: url('https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-14-20-10-56-940-585x390.jpg');\" href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2026/02/crew-12-launch/\" title=\"Crew-12 arrives at the ISS\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t                        </a>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t                        <h3>\n                            <a #header-search -->\n</div><!-- .header-search-contain -->\n\t\t\t\t\t</div><!-- .wrapper -->\n\t\t\t\t</div><!-- .bottom-header-contain -->\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"highlight-menu-contain desktop-only\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"wrapper\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<nav class=\"highlight-menu\" aria-label=\"Highlight Menu\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<ul id=\"menu-topics\" class=\"menu\"><li><span class=\"menu-label\">TOPICS:</span></li><li id=\"menu-item-525970\" class=\"menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-525970\"><a href=\"/goldendome\">Golden Dome</a></li>\n<li id=\"menu-item-525972\" class=\"menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-525972\"><a href=\"/tag/europe\">Europe</a></li>\n<li id=\"menu-item-525973\" class=\"menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-525973\"><a href=\"/tag/fundraising\">Funding Rounds</a></li>\n<li id=\"menu-item-525974\" class=\"menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-category menu-item-525974\"><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/section/civil1/\">Civil</a></li>\n<li id=\"menu-item-525975\" class=\"menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-category current-post-ancestor current-menu-parent current-post-parent menu-item-525975\"><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/section/commercial-archive/\">Commercial</a></li>\n<li id=\"menu-item-525976\" class=\"menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-category menu-item-525976\"><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/section/launch-archive/\">Launch</a></li>\n<li id=\"menu-item-525977\" class=\"menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-category menu-item-525977\"><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/section/militaryspace-archive/\">Military</a></li>\n</ul>\t\t\t\t\t\t</nav>\n\t\t\t\t\t</div><!-- .wrapper -->\n\t\t\t\t</div><!-- .highlight-menu-contain -->\n\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t</header><!-- #masthead -->\n\n\t<div class=\"site-breadcrumb desktop-only\"><div class=\"wrapper\"><span><span><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/\">Home</a></span> / <span class=\"breadcrumb_last\" aria-current=\"page\"><strong>German defense firm said to be weighing bid for Mynaric</strong></span></span></div></div>\n\t\n\t\n\t<div id=\"content\" class=\"site-content\">\n\n\t<section id=\"primary\" class=\"content-area category-commercial-archive category-news-archive tag-europe tag-germany tag-laser-communications tag-mynaric tag-rocket-lab tag-sn\">\n\t\t<main id=\"main\" class=\"site-main\">\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<header class=\"entry-header\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\n\t<span class=\"cat-links\"><span class=\"screen-reader-text\">Posted in</span><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/section/commercial-archive/\" rel=\"category tag\">Commercial</a></span>\t\t\t<h1 class=\"entry-title entry-title--with-subtitle\">\n\t\t\tGerman defense firm said to be weighing bid for Mynaric\t\t</h1>\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"newspack-post-subtitle\">\n\t\t\tRheinmetall’s reported interest in the laser communications firm would complicate Rocket Lab’s planned acquisition\t\t</div>\n\t\n\t<div class=\"entry-subhead\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"entry-meta\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"author-avatar\"><img data-perfmatters-preload width=\"80\" class=\"byline\">\n\t\t\t\t<span>by</span>\n\t\t\t\t<span class=\"author vcard\"><a class=\"url fn n\" href=\"https://spacenews.com/author/sandra-erwin/\">Sandra Erwin</a></span> \t\t\t</span><!-- .byline -->\n\t\t\t<span class=\"posted-on\"><time class=\"entry-date published\" datetime=\"2026-02-22T06:50:26-05:00\">February 22, 2026</time><time class=\"updated\" class=\"main-content\">\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t<figure class=\"post-thumbnail\">\n\n\t\t\t\t<img width=\"780\" height=\"438\" https://i0.wp.com/spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/FocqgZhaUAECh_z-scaled.jpeg?resize=768%2C432&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/FocqgZhaUAECh_z-scaled.jpeg?resize=1536%2C864&amp;ssl=1 1536w, https://i0.wp.com/spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/FocqgZhaUAECh_z-scaled.jpeg?resize=2048%2C1152&amp;ssl=1 2048w, https://i0.wp.com/spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/FocqgZhaUAECh_z-scaled.jpeg?resize=1200%2C675&amp;ssl=1 1200w, https://i0.wp.com/spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/FocqgZhaUAECh_z-scaled.jpeg?resize=1568%2C882&amp;ssl=1 1568w, https://i0.wp.com/spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/FocqgZhaUAECh_z-scaled.jpeg?resize=400%2C225&amp;ssl=1 400w, https://i0.wp.com/spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/FocqgZhaUAECh_z-scaled.jpeg?fit=780%2C438&amp;ssl=1&amp;w=370 370w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 780px) 100vw, 780px\" />\t\t\t<figcaption><span>Mynaric's optical terminal manufacturing facility.  <span class=\"image-credit\"><span class=\"credit-label-wrapper\">Credit:</span> Mynaric</span></span></figcaption>\n\t\t\t\n\t\t\t</figure><!-- .post-thumbnail -->\n\n\t\t\n\n<article id=\"post-575189\" class=\"post-575189 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-commercial-archive category-news-archive tag-europe tag-germany tag-laser-communications tag-mynaric tag-rocket-lab tag-sn membership-content access-restricted entry\">\n\t<div class=\"entry-content\">\n\n\t\t\n\t\t\n<p>WASHINGTON — Rheinmetall, Germany’s largest defense contractor, is weighing a potential acquisition of Munich-based laser communications terminal maker Mynaric, a move that could upend Rocket Lab’s previously announced plan to buy the company.</p>\n\n<p><a href=\"https://www.welt.de/wirtschaft/article699846344f25149ec09b0512/mynaric-rheinmetall-erwaegt-uebernahme-von-deutschem-laser-spezialisten.html\">German media</a> first reported Rheinmetall’s interest, citing a desire to keep critical aerospace and laser communications technology under German and European control. Rheinmetall has not commented publicly. The reports come as Germany and other European nations intensify scrutiny of foreign takeovers involving sensitive defense technologies.</p>\n\n<p>Rocket Lab, the Long Beach, Calif.-based launch services provider and satellite manufacturer, said in March it planned to acquire Mynaric for roughly $150 million, subject to approval by German authorities under foreign direct investment rules. Nearly a year later, regulators have yet to sign off, and the deal has drawn heightened political attention as Europe accelerates efforts to build domestic space and defense capacity.</p>\n\n<p>The backdrop is Germany’s sharp increase in defense spending following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and growing uncertainty about long-term U.S. security commitments. Across Europe, governments are pairing higher defense budgets with industrial policies aimed at strengthening “sovereign” technological capabilities.</p>\n\n<p>Laser communications terminals fall squarely into that category. Mynaric develops optical terminals that transmit data between satellites using laser links, a technology viewed as essential for next-generation defense and commercial constellations. Compared with traditional radio-frequency systems, laser links can move data at higher rates and with greater resistance to interference, making them attractive for military networks.</p>\n<aside>\t\t\t<div\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tclass=\"newspack-popup-container newspack-popup hidden  newspack-inline-popup      \"\n\t\t\t\trole=\"button\"\n\t\t\t\ttabindex=\"0\"\n\t\t\t\tstyle=\"background-color:#a61c20;color:#fff\"\n\t\t\t\tid=\"id_556152\"\n\t\t\t\tdata-segments=\"13521\"\n\t\t\t\tdata-frequency=\"0,0,1,day\"\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t>\n\t\t\t\t\n<div class=\"wp-block-columns is-style-borders is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-9d6595d7 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex\">\n<div class=\"wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-center is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow\" style=\"flex-basis:50%\">\n<p class=\"has-text-align-left has-normal-font-size\"><strong>Subscribe Today</strong><br>Get unlimited access to SpaceNews.com and our digital magazine with a monthly, quarterly or annual subscription.</p>\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-newspack-blocks-checkout-button wp-block-button  \"><form data-checkout=\"{&quot;action_type&quot;:&quot;checkout_button&quot;,&quot;currency&quot;:&quot;USD&quot;,&quot;product_id&quot;:&quot;519854&quot;,&quot;product_type&quot;:&quot;membership&quot;,&quot;referrer&quot;:&quot;german-defense-firm-said-to-be-weighing-bid-for-mynaric&quot;,&quot;is_variable&quot;:true,&quot;variation_ids&quot;:[558699,519864,519865,519863]}\"><button class=\"wp-block-newspack-blocks-button wp-block-button__link     \" style=\"\" type=\"submit\">Checkout Now</button> <input type=\"hidden\" name=\"newspack_checkout\" value=\"1\" /><input type=\"hidden\" name=\"after_success_button_label\" value=\"Continue\" />\t\t\t<input\n\t\t\t\tname=\"newspack_popup_id\"\n\t\t\t\ttype=\"hidden\"\n\t\t\t\tvalue=\"556152\"\n\t\t\t/>\n\t\t\t<input\n\t\t\t\tname=\"prompt_title\"\n\t\t\t\ttype=\"hidden\"\n\t\t\t\tvalue=\"Subscribe to SpaceNews &#8211; First Article\"\n\t\t\t/>\n\t\t</form></div></div>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-center is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow\" style=\"flex-basis:50%\">\n<p><strong>Discounted Access</strong> <br>Learn more about savings available for academic, government and military readers on SpaceNews subscriptions.</p>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-buttons is-layout-flex wp-block-buttons-is-layout-flex\">\n<div class=\"wp-block-button\"><a class=\"wp-block-button__link wp-element-button\" href=\"https://spacenews.com/subscribe/#subscriptions-discounts\">Save on SpaceNews</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</aside>\n\n<p>Mynaric’s CONDOR Mk3 optical terminal is designed for inter-satellite links and is already flying on spacecraft procured by the U.S. Space Development Agency for the Proliferated Warfighter Space Architecture, a planned constellation of low Earth orbit defense satellites intended to provide resilient communications and missile-tracking capabilities.</p>\n\n<p>For Rocket Lab, acquiring Mynaric would secure access to a critical subsystem and expand its footprint in Europe. The company has been building out its satellite manufacturing business alongside its launch operations and has positioned itself as an end-to-end provider of space services. Control over laser communications technology would reduce reliance on external suppliers for satellites destined for U.S. government and allied customers.</p>\n\n<p>Mynaric, for its part, has faced financial strains in recent years as it scaled production and worked through manufacturing setbacks. Despite those challenges, its technology has become strategically significant as Western governments push to deploy proliferated constellations in low Earth orbit.</p>\n\n<div id='jp-relatedposts' class='jp-relatedposts' >\n\t<h3 class=\"jp-relatedposts-headline\"><em>Related</em></h3>\n</div>\t</div><!-- .entry-content -->\n\n\t<footer class=\"entry-footer\">\n\t\t<span class=\"tags-links\"><span>Tagged: </span><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/tag/europe/\" rel=\"tag\">Europe</a><span class=\"sep\">,&nbsp;</span><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/tag/germany/\" rel=\"tag\">Germany</a><span class=\"sep\">,&nbsp;</span><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/tag/laser-communications/\" rel=\"tag\">laser communications</a><span class=\"sep\">,&nbsp;</span><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/tag/mynaric/\" rel=\"tag\">Mynaric</a><span class=\"sep\">,&nbsp;</span><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/tag/rocket-lab/\" rel=\"tag\">Rocket Lab</a><span class=\"sep\">,&nbsp;</span><a href=\"https://spacenews.com/tag/sn/\" rel=\"tag\">SN</a></span>\t</footer><!-- .entry-footer -->\n\n\t\n\t\t\t<div class=\"author-bio\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://spacenews.com/author/sandra-erwin/\" rel=\"author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<img data-perfmatters-preload width=\"80\" height=\"80\" src=\"https://spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/Sandra-Erwin-150x150.jpg\" class=\"avatar avatar-80 photo wp-post-image\" alt srcset=\"https://i0.wp.com/spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/Sandra-Erwin.jpg?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w, https://i0.wp.com/spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/art2-20260202.jpeg?resize=706%2C471&amp;ssl=1 706w, https://i0.wp.com/spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/art2-20260202.jpeg?w=2340&amp;ssl=1 2340w, https://i0.wp.com/spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/art2-20260202.jpeg?fit=1200%2C800&amp;ssl=1&amp;w=370 370w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" />\t\t\t<figcaption><span>SLS and Orion on the pad during the Artemis 2 wet dress rehearsal Feb. 2. <span class=\"image-credit\"><span class=\"credit-label-wrapper\">Credit:</span> NASA/John Kraus</span></span></figcaption>\n\t\t\t\n\t\t\t</figure><!-- .post-thumbnail -->\n\n\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"main-content\">\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\n\n<article id=\"post-575109\" class=\"post-575109 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-civil1 category-launch-archive category-news-archive tag-artemis tag-artemis-2 tag-nasa tag-sls tag-sn membership-content access-restricted entry\">\n\t<div class=\"entry-content\">\n\n\t\t\n\t\t\n<p><em>Updated 12:15 p.m. Eastern with additional comments from Isaacman.</em></p>\n\n<p>WASHINGTON — Just 24 hours after setting a March 6 launch date for the Artemis 2 mission, NASA announced Feb. 21 that a problem with the Space Launch System upper stage will delay the launch.</p>\n\n<p>In a brief <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/blogs/missions/2026/02/21/nasa-troubleshooting-artemis-ii-rocket-upper-stage-issue-preparing-to-roll-back/\">statement</a>, NASA said it was preparing to roll the SLS back from Launch Complex 39B at the Kennedy Space Center to the Vehicle Assembly Building after engineers found that helium flow in the rocket’s upper stage had been interrupted.</p>\n\n<p>Helium is used to pressurize tanks in the stage, formally known as the Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage. NASA had not reported any issues with helium flow or tank pressurization during a second wet dress rehearsal that concluded late Feb. 19.</p>\n\n<p>NASA initially said it had not yet made a final decision to roll the vehicle back to the Vehicle Assembly Building, or VAB, and was studying options to fix the problem at the pad as well as inside the VAB. However, in a social media <a href=\"https://x.com/NASAAdmin/status/2025231621436186837\">post</a>, NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman called a rollback “likely.”</p>\n<aside>\t\t\t<div\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tclass=\"newspack-popup-container newspack-popup hidden  newspack-inline-popup      \"\n\t\t\t\trole=\"button\"\n\t\t\t\ttabindex=\"0\"\n\t\t\t\tstyle=\"background-color:#a61c20;color:#fff\"\n\t\t\t\tid=\"id_556152\"\n\t\t\t\tdata-segments=\"13521\"\n\t\t\t\tdata-frequency=\"0,0,1,day\"\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t>\n\t\t\t\t\n<div class=\"wp-block-columns is-style-borders is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-9d6595d7 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex\">\n<div class=\"wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-center is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow\" style=\"flex-basis:50%\">\n<p class=\"has-text-align-left has-normal-font-size\"><strong>Subscribe Today</strong><br>Get unlimited access to SpaceNews.com and our digital magazine with a monthly, quarterly or annual subscription.</p>\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-newspack-blocks-checkout-button wp-block-button  \"><form data-checkout=\"{&quot;action_type&quot;:&quot;checkout_button&quot;,&quot;currency&quot;:&quot;USD&quot;,&quot;product_id&quot;:&quot;519854&quot;,&quot;product_type&quot;:&quot;membership&quot;,&quot;referrer&quot;:&quot;nasa-preparing-for-artemis-2-rollback-to-fix-upper-stage-problem&quot;,&quot;is_variable&quot;:true,&quot;variation_ids&quot;:[558699,519864,519865,519863]}\"><button class=\"wp-block-newspack-blocks-button wp-block-button__link     \" style=\"\" type=\"submit\">Checkout Now</button> <input type=\"hidden\" name=\"newspack_checkout\" value=\"1\" /><input type=\"hidden\" name=\"after_success_button_label\" value=\"Continue\" />\t\t\t<input\n\t\t\t\tname=\"newspack_popup_id\"\n\t\t\t\ttype=\"hidden\"\n\t\t\t\tvalue=\"556152\"\n\t\t\t/>\n\t\t\t<input\n\t\t\t\tname=\"prompt_title\"\n\t\t\t\ttype=\"hidden\"\n\t\t\t\tvalue=\"Subscribe to SpaceNews &#8211; First Article\"\n\t\t\t/>\n\t\t</form></div></div>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-center is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow\" style=\"flex-basis:50%\">\n<p><strong>Discounted Access</strong> <br>Learn more about savings available for academic, government and military readers on SpaceNews subscriptions.</p>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-buttons is-layout-flex wp-block-buttons-is-layout-flex\">\n<div class=\"wp-block-button\"><a class=\"wp-block-button__link wp-element-button\" href=\"https://spacenews.com/subscribe/#subscriptions-discounts\">Save on SpaceNews</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</aside>\n\n<p>In a subsequent <a href=\"https://x.com/NASAAdmin/status/2025249086908125630\">post</a>, Isaacman said that while several potential causes for the problem, also seen during Artemis 1, were being considered, NASA would proceed with a rollback. &#8220;Regardless of the potential fault, accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB,&#8221; he stated.</p>\n\n<p>While studying repair options, workers began preparing for a potential rollback. That includes disassembling temporary work platforms that had just been installed at the launch pad for tasks such as retesting the rocket’s flight termination system. That work could not wait until Feb. 22, the agency said, because of high winds forecast that day.</p>\n\n<p>The announcement came a day after agency officials said at a briefing that <a href=\"https://spacenews.com/nasa-targeting-march-6-for-artemis-2-launch/\">they were working toward launching Artemis 2 as soon as March 6</a>, the first day of the next launch period for the mission. That opportunity runs through March 11.</p>\n\n<p>The upper stage problem and possible rollback “will almost assuredly impact the March launch window,” NASA said.</p>\n\n<p>Isaacman stated that the rollback &#8220;will take the March launch window out of consideration.&#8221;</p>\n\n<p>At the Feb. 20 briefing, NASA cautioned that work remained to prepare Artemis 2 for a March launch, including pad activities and a multiday flight readiness review.</p>\n\n<p>“But assuming that happens, it puts us in a very good position to target March 6,” said Lori Glaze, acting associate administrator for exploration systems development.</p>\n\n<p>“I’ve got a pretty high level of confidence in the configuration that we’re in right now,” added John Honeycutt, chair of NASA’s Artemis 2 mission management team. “It’s out there at the pad. It’s going to be there at the pad until we go fly.”</p>\n\n<p>If NASA is unable to launch Artemis 2 in March, the next launch window runs from April 1 to 6. Another window opens April 30, although NASA has not disclosed additional launch opportunities beyond the end of April.</p>\n\n<p>&#8220;I understand people are disappointed by this development. That disappointment is felt most by the team at NASA, who have been working tirelessly to prepare for this great endeavor,&#8221; Isaacman said, but noted there were &#8220;many setbacks&#8221; during the Apollo program before landing people on the moon in 1969.</p>\n\n<div id='jp-relatedposts' class='jp-relatedposts' >\n\t<h3 class=\"jp-relatedposts-headline\"><em>Related</em></h3>\n</div>\t</div><!-- .entry-content -->\n\n\t<footer class=\"entry-footer\">\n\t\t<span class=\"tags-links\"><span>Tagged: </span><a zone-alias=\"\"></spacenews-zone></div>\t\t</div>\n\t\t\n\t</div><!-- #content -->\n\n\t<footer id=\"colophon\" class=\"site-footer\">\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\n\t<aside class=\"widget-area footer-widgets\" role=\"complementary\" aria-label=\"Footer\">\n\t\t<div class=\"wrapper\">\n\t\t\t<section id=\"block-43\" class=\"widget widget_block\">\n<div class=\"wp-block-group has-primary-background-color                         "json": {
                          "title": "German defense firm said to be weighing bid for Mynaric",
                          "url": "https://spacenews.com/german-defense-firm-said-to-be-weighing-bid-for-mynaric/",
                          "date": "February 22, 2026",
                          "thumbnail": "https://spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/FocqgZhaUAECh_z-scaled.jpeg",
                          "images": [],
                          "source": "SpaceNews",
                          "content": "WASHINGTON — Rheinmetall, Germany’s largest defense contractor, is weighing a potential acquisition of Munich-based laser communications terminal maker Mynaric, a move that could upend Rocket Lab’s previously announced plan to buy the company. German media first reported Rheinmetall’s interest, citing a desire to keep critical aerospace and laser communications technology under German and European control. Rheinmetall has not commented publicly. The reports come as Germany and other European nations intensify scrutiny of foreign takeovers involving sensitive defense technologies. Rocket Lab, the Long Beach, Calif.-based launch services provider and satellite manufacturer, said in March it planned to acquire Mynaric for roughly $150 million, subject to approval by German authorities under foreign direct investment rules. Nearly a year later, regulators have yet to sign off, and the deal has drawn heightened political attention as Europe accelerates efforts to build domestic space and defense capacity. The backdrop is Germany’s sharp increase in defense spending following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and growing uncertainty about long-term U.S. security commitments. Across Europe, governments are pairing higher defense budgets with industrial policies aimed at strengthening “sovereign” technological capabilities. Laser communications terminals fall squarely into that category. Mynaric develops optical terminals that transmit data between satellites using laser links, a technology viewed as essential for next-generation defense and commercial constellations. Compared with traditional radio-frequency systems, laser links can move data at higher rates and with greater resistance to interference, making them attractive for military networks. Subscribe Today Get unlimited access to SpaceNews.com and our digital magazine with a monthly, quarterly or annual subscription. Checkout Now Discounted Access Learn more about savings available for academic, government and military readers on SpaceNews subscriptions. Save on SpaceNews Mynaric’s CONDOR Mk3 optical terminal is designed for inter-satellite links and is already flying on spacecraft procured by the U.S. Space Development Agency for the Proliferated Warfighter Space Architecture, a planned constellation of low Earth orbit defense satellites intended to provide resilient communications and missile-tracking capabilities. For Rocket Lab, acquiring Mynaric would secure access to a critical subsystem and expand its footprint in Europe. The company has been building out its satellite manufacturing business alongside its launch operations and has positioned itself as an end-to-end provider of space services. Control over laser communications technology would reduce reliance on external suppliers for satellites destined for U.S. government and allied customers. Mynaric, for its part, has faced financial strains in recent years as it scaled production and worked through manufacturing setbacks. Despite those challenges, its technology has become strategically significant as Western governments push to deploy proliferated constellations in low Earth orbit.",
                          "raw_html_content": "<p>WASHINGTON — Rheinmetall, Germany’s largest defense contractor, is weighing a potential acquisition of Munich-based laser communications terminal maker Mynaric, a move that could upend Rocket Lab’s previously announced plan to buy the company.</p>\n\n<p><a href=\"https://www.welt.de/wirtschaft/article699846344f25149ec09b0512/mynaric-rheinmetall-erwaegt-uebernahme-von-deutschem-laser-spezialisten.html\">German media</a> first reported Rheinmetall’s interest, citing a desire to keep critical aerospace and laser communications technology under German and European control. Rheinmetall has not commented publicly. The reports come as Germany and other European nations intensify scrutiny of foreign takeovers involving sensitive defense technologies.</p>\n\n<p>Rocket Lab, the Long Beach, Calif.-based launch services provider and satellite manufacturer, said in March it planned to acquire Mynaric for roughly $150 million, subject to approval by German authorities under foreign direct investment rules. Nearly a year later, regulators have yet to sign off, and the deal has drawn heightened political attention as Europe accelerates efforts to build domestic space and defense capacity.</p>\n\n<p>The backdrop is Germany’s sharp increase in defense spending following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and growing uncertainty about long-term U.S. security commitments. Across Europe, governments are pairing higher defense budgets with industrial policies aimed at strengthening “sovereign” technological capabilities.</p>\n\n<p>Laser communications terminals fall squarely into that category. Mynaric develops optical terminals that transmit data between satellites using laser links, a technology viewed as essential for next-generation defense and commercial constellations. Compared with traditional radio-frequency systems, laser links can move data at higher rates and with greater resistance to interference, making them attractive for military networks.</p>\n<aside>\t\t\t<div\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tclass=\"newspack-popup-container newspack-popup hidden  newspack-inline-popup      \"\n\t\t\t\trole=\"button\"\n\t\t\t\ttabindex=\"0\"\n\t\t\t\tstyle=\"background-color:#a61c20;color:#fff\"\n\t\t\t\tid=\"id_556152\"\n\t\t\t\tdata-segments=\"13521\"\n\t\t\t\tdata-frequency=\"0,0,1,day\"\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t>\n\t\t\t\t\n<div class=\"wp-block-columns is-style-borders is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-9d6595d7 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex\">\n<div class=\"wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-center is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow\" style=\"flex-basis:50%\">\n<p class=\"has-text-align-left has-normal-font-size\"><strong>Subscribe Today</strong><br>Get unlimited access to SpaceNews.com and our digital magazine with a monthly, quarterly or annual subscription.</p>\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-newspack-blocks-checkout-button wp-block-button  \"><form data-checkout=\"{&quot;action_type&quot;:&quot;checkout_button&quot;,&quot;currency&quot;:&quot;USD&quot;,&quot;product_id&quot;:&quot;519854&quot;,&quot;product_type&quot;:&quot;membership&quot;,&quot;referrer&quot;:&quot;german-defense-firm-said-to-be-weighing-bid-for-mynaric&quot;,&quot;is_variable&quot;:true,&quot;variation_ids&quot;:[558699,519864,519865,519863]}\"><button class=\"wp-block-newspack-blocks-button wp-block-button__link     \" style=\"\" type=\"submit\">Checkout Now</button> <input type=\"hidden\" name=\"newspack_checkout\" value=\"1\" /><input type=\"hidden\" name=\"after_success_button_label\" value=\"Continue\" />\t\t\t<input\n\t\t\t\tname=\"newspack_popup_id\"\n\t\t\t\ttype=\"hidden\"\n\t\t\t\tvalue=\"556152\"\n\t\t\t/>\n\t\t\t<input\n\t\t\t\tname=\"prompt_title\"\n\t\t\t\ttype=\"hidden\"\n\t\t\t\tvalue=\"Subscribe to SpaceNews &#8211;
