                        "json": {
                          "title": "NASA preparing for Artemis 2 rollback to fix upper stage problem",
                          "url": "https://spacenews.com/nasa-preparing-for-artemis-2-rollback-to-fix-upper-stage-problem/",
                          "date": "February 21, 2026",
                          "thumbnail": "https://spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/art2-20260202.jpeg",
                          "images": [],
                          "source": "SpaceNews",
                          "content": "Updated 12:15 p.m. Eastern with additional comments from Isaacman. WASHINGTON — Just 24 hours after setting a March 6 launch date for the Artemis 2 mission, NASA announced Feb. 21 that a problem with the Space Launch System upper stage will delay the launch. In a brief statement , NASA said it was preparing to roll the SLS back from Launch Complex 39B at the Kennedy Space Center to the Vehicle Assembly Building after engineers found that helium flow in the rocket’s upper stage had been interrupted. Helium is used to pressurize tanks in the stage, formally known as the Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage. NASA had not reported any issues with helium flow or tank pressurization during a second wet dress rehearsal that concluded late Feb. 19. NASA initially said it had not yet made a final decision to roll the vehicle back to the Vehicle Assembly Building, or VAB, and was studying options to fix the problem at the pad as well as inside the VAB. However, in a social media post , NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman called a rollback “likely.” Subscribe Today Get unlimited access to SpaceNews.com and our digital magazine with a monthly, quarterly or annual subscription. Checkout Now Discounted Access Learn more about savings available for academic, government and military readers on SpaceNews subscriptions. Save on SpaceNews In a subsequent post , Isaacman said that while several potential causes for the problem, also seen during Artemis 1, were being considered, NASA would proceed with a rollback. \"Regardless of the potential fault, accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB,\" he stated. While studying repair options, workers began preparing for a potential rollback. That includes disassembling temporary work platforms that had just been installed at the launch pad for tasks such as retesting the rocket’s flight termination system. That work could not wait until Feb. 22, the agency said, because of high winds forecast that day. The announcement came a day after agency officials said at a briefing that they were working toward launching Artemis 2 as soon as March 6 , the first day of the next launch period for the mission. That opportunity runs through March 11. The upper stage problem and possible rollback “will almost assuredly impact the March launch window,” NASA said. Isaacman stated that the rollback \"will take the March launch window out of consideration.\" At the Feb. 20 briefing, NASA cautioned that work remained to prepare Artemis 2 for a March launch, including pad activities and a multiday flight readiness review. “But assuming that happens, it puts us in a very good position to target March 6,” said Lori Glaze, acting associate administrator for exploration systems development. “I’ve got a pretty high level of confidence in the configuration that we’re in right now,” added John Honeycutt, chair of NASA’s Artemis 2 mission management team. “It’s out there at the pad. It’s going to be there at the pad until we go fly.” If NASA is unable to launch Artemis 2 in March, the next launch window runs from April 1 to 6. Another window opens April 30, although NASA has not disclosed additional launch opportunities beyond the end of April. \"I understand people are disappointed by this development. That disappointment is felt most by the team at NASA, who have been working tirelessly to prepare for this great endeavor,\" Isaacman said, but noted there were \"many setbacks\" during the Apollo program before landing people on the moon in 1969.",
                          "raw_html_content": "<p><em>Updated 12:15 p.m. Eastern with additional comments from Isaacman.</em></p>\n\n<p>WASHINGTON — Just 24 hours after setting a March 6 launch date for the Artemis 2 mission, NASA announced Feb. 21 that a problem with the Space Launch System upper stage will delay the launch.</p>\n\n<p>In a brief <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/blogs/missions/2026/02/21/nasa-troubleshooting-artemis-ii-rocket-upper-stage-issue-preparing-to-roll-back/\">statement</a>, NASA said it was preparing to roll the SLS back from Launch Complex 39B at the Kennedy Space Center to the Vehicle Assembly Building after engineers found that helium flow in the rocket’s upper stage had been interrupted.</p>\n\n<p>Helium is used to pressurize tanks in the stage, formally known as the Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage. NASA had not reported any issues with helium flow or tank pressurization during a second wet dress rehearsal that concluded late Feb. 19.</p>\n\n<p>NASA initially said it had not yet made a final decision to roll the vehicle back to the Vehicle Assembly Building, or VAB, and was studying options to fix the problem at the pad as well as inside the VAB. However, in a social media <a href=\"https://x.com/NASAAdmin/status/2025231621436186837\">post</a>, NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman called a rollback “likely.”</p>\n<aside>\t\t\t<div\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tclass=\"newspack-popup-container newspack-popup hidden  newspack-inline-popup      \"\n\t\t\t\trole=\"button\"\n\t\t\t\ttabindex=\"0\"\n\t\t\t\tstyle=\"background-color:#a61c20;color:#fff\"\n\t\t\t\tid=\"id_556152\"\n\t\t\t\tdata-segments=\"13521\"\n\t\t\t\tdata-frequency=\"0,0,1,day\"\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t>\n\t\t\t\t\n<div class=\"wp-block-columns is-style-borders is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-9d6595d7 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex\">\n<div class=\"wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-center is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow\" style=\"flex-basis:50%\">\n<p class=\"has-text-align-left has-normal-font-size\"><strong>Subscribe Today</strong><br>Get unlimited access to SpaceNews.com and our digital magazine with a monthly, quarterly or annual subscription.</p>\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-newspack-blocks-checkout-button wp-block-button  \"><form data-checkout=\"{&quot;action_type&quot;:&quot;checkout_button&quot;,&quot;currency&quot;:&quot;USD&quot;,&quot;product_id&quot;:&quot;519854&quot;,&quot;product_type&quot;:&quot;membership&quot;,&quot;referrer&quot;:&quot;nasa-preparing-for-artemis-2-rollback-to-fix-upper-stage-problem&quot;,&quot;is_variable&quot;:true,&quot;variation_ids&quot;:[558699,519864,519865,519863]}\"><button class=\"wp-block-newspack-blocks-button wp-block-button__link     \" style=\"\" type=\"submit\">Checkout Now</button> <input type=\"hidden\" name=\"newspack_checkout\" value=\"1\" /><input type=\"hidden\" name=\"after_success_button_label\" value=\"Continue\" />\t\t\t<input\n\t\t\t\tname=\"newspack_popup_id\"\n\t\t\t\ttype=\"hidden\"\n\t\t\t\tvalue=\"556152\"\n\t\t\t/>\n\t\t\t<input\n\t\t\t\tname=\"prompt_title\"\n\t\t\t\ttype=\"hidden\"\n\t\t\t\tvalue=\"Subscribe to SpaceNews &#8211; First Article\"\n\t\t\t/>\n\t\t</form></div></div>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-center is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow\" style=\"flex-basis:50%\">\n<p><strong>Discounted Access</strong> <br>Learn more about savings available for academic, government and military readers on SpaceNews subscriptions.</p>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-buttons is-layout-flex wp-block-buttons-is-layout-flex\">\n<div class=\"wp-block-button\"><a class=\"wp-block-button__link wp-element-button\" href=\"https://spacenews.com/subscribe/#subscriptions-discounts\">Save on SpaceNews</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</aside>\n\n<p>In a subsequent <a href=\"https://x.com/NASAAdmin/status/2025249086908125630\">post</a>, Isaacman said that while several potential causes for the problem, also seen during Artemis 1, were being considered, NASA would proceed with a rollback. &#8220;Regardless of the potential fault, accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB,&#8221; he stated.</p>\n\n<p>While studying repair options, workers began preparing for a potential rollback. That includes disassembling temporary work platforms that had just been installed at the launch pad for tasks such as retesting the rocket’s flight termination system. That work could not wait until Feb. 22, the agency said, because of high winds forecast that day.</p>\n\n<p>The announcement came a day after agency officials said at a briefing that <a href=\"https://spacenews.com/nasa-targeting-march-6-for-artemis-2-launch/\">they were working toward launching Artemis 2 as soon as March 6</a>, the first day of the next launch period for the mission. That opportunity runs through March 11.</p>\n\n<p>The upper stage problem and possible rollback “will almost assuredly impact the March launch window,” NASA said.</p>\n\n<p>Isaacman stated that the rollback &#8220;will take the March launch window out of consideration.&#8221;</p>\n\n<p>At the Feb. 20 briefing, NASA cautioned that work remained to prepare Artemis 2 for a March launch, including pad activities and a multiday flight readiness review.</p>\n\n<p>“But assuming that happens, it puts us in a very good position to target March 6,” said Lori Glaze, acting associate administrator for exploration systems development.</p>\n\n<p>“I’ve got a pretty high level of confidence in the configuration that we’re in right now,” added John Honeycutt, chair of NASA’s Artemis 2 mission management team. “It’s out there at the pad. It’s going to be there at the pad until we go fly.”</p>\n\n<p>If NASA is unable to launch Artemis 2 in March, the next launch window runs from April 1 to 6. Another window opens April 30, although NASA has not disclosed additional launch opportunities beyond the end of April.</p>\n\n<p>&#8220;I understand people are disappointed by this development. That disappointment is felt most by the team at NASA, who have been working tirelessly to prepare for this great endeavor,&#8221; Isaacman said, but noted there were &#8220;many setbacks&#8221; during the Apollo program before landing people on the moon in 1969.</p>",

mh-ticker-item-bottom\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2026/02/20/moon-mission-fueling-test-concludes-with-no-major-problems/\" title=\"Moon mission fueling test concludes with no major problems\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-date mh-ticker-item-date-bottom\">\r\n                        \t[ February 20, 2026 ]                        </span>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-title mh-ticker-item-title-bottom\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\tMoon mission fueling test concludes with no major problems\t\t\t\t\t\t</span>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-cat mh-ticker-item-cat-bottom\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<i class=\"fa fa-caret-right\"></i>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tArtemis\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</span>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</a>\r\n\t\t\t\t</li>\t\t\t\t<li class=\"mh-ticker-item mh-ticker-item-bottom\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2026/02/19/independent-report-sharply-criticizes-nasa-management-boeing-for-troubled-starliner-flight/\" title=\"Independent report sharply criticizes NASA management, Boeing for troubled Starliner flight\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-date mh-ticker-item-date-bottom\">\r\n                        \t[ February 19, 2026 ]                        </span>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-title mh-ticker-item-title-bottom\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\tIndependent report sharply criticizes NASA management, Boeing for troubled Starliner flight\t\t\t\t\t\t</span>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-cat mh-ticker-item-cat-bottom\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<i class=\"fa fa-caret-right\"></i>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tMission Reports\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</span>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</a>\r\n\t\t\t\t</li>\t\t</ul>\r\n\t</div>\r\n</div>\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"mh-header-bar-content mh-header-bar-bottom-right mh-col-1-3 clearfix\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n<div class=\"mh-wrapper clearfix\">\n\t<div class=\"mh-main clearfix\">\n\t\t<div id=\"main-content\" class=\"mh-content\" role=\"main\" itemprop=\"mainContentOfPage\"><article id=\"post-72650\" class=\"post-72650 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-falcon-9 category-mission-reports category-news-archive category-x-sidebar tag-asog tag-b1067 tag-falcon-9 tag-slc-40 tag-sld-45 tag-spacex tag-starlink tag-starlink-6-104\">\n\t<header class=\"entry-header clearfix\"><h1 class=\"entry-title\">SpaceX’s most-flown Falcon booster launches on record 33rd flight</h1><div class=\"mh-meta entry-meta\">\n<span class=\"entry-meta-date updated\"><i class=\"fa fa-clock-o\"></i><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2026/02/\">February 21, 2026</a></span>\n<span class=\"entry-meta-author author vcard\"><i class=\"fa fa-user\"></i><a class=\"fn\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/author/will-the-robinson-smith/\">Will Robinson-Smith</a></span>\n</div>\n\t</header>\n\t\t<div class=\"entry-content clearfix\"><figure id=\"attachment_72653\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-72653\" style=\"width: 678px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img fetchpriority=\"high\" decoding=\"async\" class=\"size-full wp-image-72653\" src=\"http://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260221_Starlink_6-104_MC-1.jpeg\" alt=\"\" width=\"678\" height=\"452\" srcset=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260221_Starlink_6-104_MC-1.jpeg 678w, https://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260221_Starlink_6-104_MC-1-300x200.jpeg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 678px) 100vw, 678px\" /><figcaption id=\"caption-attachment-72653\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket lifts off from Space Launch Complex 40 (SLC-40) at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station to begin the Starlink 6-104 mission on Feb. 21, 2026. Image: Michael Cain/Spaceflight Now</figcaption></figure>\n<p><em><strong>Update Feb. 21, 12 a.m. EST (0500 UTC): SpaceX confirms satellite deployment.</strong></em></p>\n<p>SpaceX’s most flown Falcon 9 rocket booster launched once again Saturday night, making its 33rd mission to space and back as the company works to certify its boosters for up to 40 flights each.</p>\n<p>The Starlink 6-104 mission added another 28 broadband internet satellites to SpaceX’s growing low Earth orbit constellation of more than 9,700 satellites.</p>\n<p>Liftoff from Space Launch Complex 40 (SLC-40) at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station happened at 10:47 p.m. EST (0347 UTC). The Falcon 9 rocket flew on a south-easterly trajectory upon leaving the pad.</p>\n<p><iframe title=\"YouTube video player\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/r2t9aB0pemM?si=dUiTySbeJbuhto1H\" width=\"678\" height=\"381\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"><span data-mce-type=\"bookmark\" style=\"display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;\" class=\"mce_SELRES_start\">﻿</span></iframe></p>\n<p>The 45th Weather Squadron forecast a greater than 95 percent chance for favorable weather during liftoff, citing no specific meteorological concerns.</p>\n<p>The 33rd flight of Falcon 9 booster 1067 came about 2.5 months after its previous launch in early December. Its previous missions include four flights for NASA, the European Commission’s Galileo L13, and 20 batches of Starlink satellites.</p>\n<p>Nearly 8.5 minutes after liftoff, B1067 landed on the droneship, ‘A Shortfall of Gravitas,’ positioned in the Atlantic Ocean. This was the 143rd landing on this vessel and the 575th booster landing to date for SpaceX.</p>\n<figure id=\"attachment_72654\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-72654\" style=\"width: 678px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img decoding=\"async\" class=\"size-full wp-image-72654\" src=\"http://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260221_Starlink_6-104_AB-1.jpeg\" alt=\"\" width=\"678\" height=\"446\" srcset=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260221_Starlink_6-104_AB-1.jpeg 678w, https://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260221_Starlink_6-104_AB-1-300x197.jpeg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 678px) 100vw, 678px\" /><figcaption id=\"caption-attachment-72654\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">A streak shot of SpaceX&#8217;s Falcon 9 rocket as it lifts off from Space Launch Complex 40 (SLC-40) at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station to begin the Starlink 6-104 mission on Feb. 21, 2026. Image: Adam Bernstein/Spaceflight Now</figcaption></figure>\n\t</div><div class=\"entry-tags clearfix\"><i class=\"fa fa-tag\"></i><ul><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/asog/\" rel=\"tag\">ASOG</a></li><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/b1067/\" rel=\"tag\">B1067</a></li><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/falcon-9/\" rel=\"tag\">Falcon 9</a></li><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/slc-40/\" rel=\"tag\">SLC-40</a></li><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/sld-45/\" rel=\"tag\">SLD 45</a></li><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/spacex/\" rel=\"tag\">SpaceX</a></li><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/starlink/\" rel=\"tag\">Starlink</a></li><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/starlink-6-104/\" rel=\"tag\">Starlink 6-104</a></li></ul></div></article><section class=\"mh-related-content\">\n<h3 class=\"mh-widget-title mh-related-content-title\">\n<span class=\"mh-widget-title-inner\">Related Articles</span></h3>\n<div class=\"mh-related-wrap mh-row clearfix\">\n<div class=\"mh-col-1-3 mh-posts-grid-col next-generation Iridium satellites, designed to connect global subscribers with data and voice traffic, arrived at Vandenberg Air Force Base on Tuesday, where they will join eight more message relay craft for launch in September on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket. <a class=\"mh-excerpt-more\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2016/08/03/first-two-iridium-next-satellites-shipped-to-vandenberg/\" class=\"fn\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/author/stephen-clark/\">Stephen Clark</a></span>\n</div>\n\t<div class=\"mh-posts-grid-excerpt clearfix\">\r\n\t\t<div class=\"mh-excerpt\"><p>A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket lifted off from Cape Canaveral at 10:30 p.m. EDT Thursday (0230 GMT Friday). The 229-foot-tall launch vehicle delivered 60 satellites to orbit to begin the deployment of SpaceX&#8217;s Starlink Internet network, a fleet of spacecraft that may eventually number thousands. <a class=\"mh-excerpt-more\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2019/05/15/falcon-9-starlink-1-mission-status-center/\" title=\"Live coverage: SpaceX launches 60 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 major problems\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-date mh-ticker-item-date-bottom\">\r\n                        \t[ February 20, 2026 ]                        </span>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-title mh-ticker-item-title-bottom\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\tMoon mission fueling test concludes with no major problems\t\t\t\t\t\t</span>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-cat mh-ticker-item-cat-bottom\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<i class=\"fa mh-ticker-item-bottom\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2026/02/19/independent-report-sharply-criticizes-nasa-management-boeing-for-troubled-starliner-flight/\" title=\"Independent report sharply criticizes NASA management, Boeing for troubled Starliner flight\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-date mh-ticker-item-date-bottom\">\r\n                        \t[ February 19, 2026 ]                        </span>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-title mh-ticker-item-title-bottom\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\tIndependent report sharply criticizes NASA management, Boeing for troubled Starliner flight\t\t\t\t\t\t</span>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"mh-ticker-item-cat mh-ticker-item-cat-bottom\">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<i class=\"fa Reports\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</span>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</a>\r\n\t\t\t\t</li>\t\t</ul>\r\n\t</div>\r\n</div>\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"mh-header-bar-content mh-header-bar-bottom-right mh-col-1-3 clearfix\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n<div class=\"mh-wrapper clearfix\">\n\t<div class=\"mh-main clearfix\">\n\t\t<div id=\"main-content\" class=\"mh-content\" role=\"main\" itemprop=\"mainContentOfPage\"><article id=\"post-72644\" class=\"post-72644 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-artemis category-mission-reports category-news-archive category-space-launch-system category-home-page-highlight tag-interim-cryogenic-propulsion-stage tag-nasa tag-space-launch-system tag-united-launch-alliance\">\n\t<header class=\"entry-header clearfix\"><h1 class=\"entry-title\">NASA&#8217;s Artemis 2 rocket hit by new problem expected to bump moonshot into early April</h1><div class=\"mh-meta entry-meta\">\n<span class=\"entry-meta-date updated\"><i class=\"fa fa-clock-o\"></i><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2026/02/\">February 21, 2026</a></span>\n<span class=\"entry-meta-author author vcard\"><i class=\"fa fa-user\"></i><a class=\"fn\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/author/bill-harwood/\">William Harwood</a></span>\n</div>\n\t</header>\n\t\t<div class=\"entry-content clearfix\"><figure id=\"attachment_72645\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-72645\" style=\"width: 678px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img fetchpriority=\"high\" decoding=\"async\" class=\"size-full wp-image-72645\" src=\"http://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260221-SLS_pad_shot_ICPS.jpeg\" alt=\"\" width=\"678\" height=\"381\" srcset=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260221-SLS_pad_shot_ICPS.jpeg 678w, https://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260221-SLS_pad_shot_ICPS-300x169.jpeg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 678px) 100vw, 678px\" /><figcaption id=\"caption-attachment-72645\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">A closeup view shows the NASA’s Artemis 2 SLS (Space Launch System) rocket with the Orion spacecraft and launch abort system atop at Launch Complex 39B at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Tuesday, Feb. 10, 2026. The Artemis 2 test flight will take Commander Reid Wiseman, Pilot Victor Glover, and Mission Specialist Christina Koch from NASA, and Mission Specialist Jeremy Hansen from the CSA (Canadian Space Agency), around the Moon and back to Earth. Image: NASA/Ben Smegelsky</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Engineers ran into problems repressurizing the Artemis 2 moon rocket’s upper stage helium tanks overnight Friday, a problem that will require rolling the huge rocket off the launch pad and back to its processing hangar for troubleshooting. The work will push the already delayed mission from March to at least early April, officials said Saturday.</p>\n<p>Pressurized helium is used to push propellants to rocket engines for ignition and to purge various fuel lines to clear them out before propellants flow. It’s not yet known what might be preventing helium to flow back into the SLS rocket’s upper stage following a successful countdown rehearsal test that ended Thursday.</p>\n<p>“Regardless of the potential fault, accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB (Vehicle Assembly Building),” NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman said in a post on the social media platform X. “We will begin preparations for rollback, and this will take the March launch window out of consideration.”</p>\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\">\n<p dir=\"ltr\" lang=\"en\">As an update to my earlier post.</p>\n<p>&#8211; The ICPS helium bottles are used to purge the engines, as well as for LH2 and LOX tank pressurization. The systems did work correctly during WDR1 and WDR2.</p>\n<p>&#8211; Last evening, the team was unable to get helium flow through the vehicle. This… <a href=\"https://t.co/Qte3nEXwQb\">https://t.co/Qte3nEXwQb</a></p>\n<p>— NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman (@NASAAdmin) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/NASAAdmin/status/2025249086908125630?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">February 21, 2026</a></p></blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p>\n<p>The Artemis 2 mission aims to send four astronauts – Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, Christina Koch and Canadian astronaut Jeremy Hansen – on a flight around the far side of the moon and back to thoroughly test the agency’s Orion deep space capsule to help clear the way for a lunar landing mission, Artemis 3, in 2028.</p>\n<p>Because of the ever-changing positions of the Earth and moon, and associated changes in lighting and other factors, only a handful of launch opportunities are available each month that meet the Artemis 2 mission requirements. The current launch period ends on March 11. The available launch dates next month are April 1, 3, 4, 5 and 6.</p>\n<p>Wiseman, Glover, Koch and Hansen originally hoped to launch early this month, but hydrogen leaks detected during an initial “wet dress countdown” rehearsal ultimately pushed the flight to March.</p>\n<figure id=\"attachment_72631\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-72631\" style=\"width: 678px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img decoding=\"async\" class=\"size-full wp-image-72631\" src=\"http://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260219_Artemis-II_WDR-2_clock.jpeg\" alt=\"\" width=\"678\" height=\"452\" srcset=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260219_Artemis-II_WDR-2_clock.jpeg 678w, https://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/20260219_Artemis-II_WDR-2_clock-300x200.jpeg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 678px) 100vw, 678px\" /><figcaption id=\"caption-attachment-72631\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">The countdown clock at the Kennedy Space Center Press Site stops at T-29 seconds at the end of the second terminal countdown demonstration, bringing an end to the wet dress rehearsal tanking test on Thursday, Feb. 19, 2026. Image: John Pisani/Spaceflight Now</figcaption></figure>\n<p>NASA completed a second fueling test and countdown Thursday, loading the Space Launch System rocket with more than 750,000 gallons of liquid oxygen and hydrogen fuel while working through the steps that will be needed to actually launch the huge rocket on the long-awaited mission.</p>\n<p>The test went well, there were no fuel leaks like the ones that derailed plans for a launch earlier this month. Managers said Friday the team would press ahead for a launch attempt on March 6 to send Wiseman and his crewmates to the moon.</p>\n<p>Hoping for the best, the astronauts went into pre-flight medical quarantine at the Johnson Space Center Friday evening and planned to fly to the Kennedy Space Center on March 1 to prepare for launch. They now will leave quarantine to await developments.</p>\n<p>“I understand people are disappointed by this development,” Isaacman said. “That disappointment is felt most by the team at NASA, who have been working tirelessly to prepare for this great endeavor. During the 1960s, when NASA achieved what most thought was impossible, and what has never been repeated since, there were many setbacks.</p>\n<p>“There are many differences between the 1960s and today, and expectations should rightfully be high after the time and expense invested in this program.</p>\n<p>“I will say again, the President created Artemis as a program that will far surpass what America achieved during Apollo. We will return in the years ahead, we will build a Moon base, and undertake what should be continuous missions to and from the lunar environment. Where we begin with this architecture and flight rate is not where it will end.”</p>\n\t</div><div class=\"entry-tags clearfix\"><i class=\"fa fa-tag\"></i><ul><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/interim-cryogenic-propulsion-stage/\" rel=\"tag\">Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage</a></li><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/nasa/\" rel=\"tag\">NASA</a></li><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/space-launch-system/\" rel=\"tag\">Space Launch System</a></li><li><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/tag/united-launch-alliance/\" rel=\"tag\">United Launch Alliance</a></li></ul></div></article><section class=\"mh-related-content\">\n<h3 class=\"mh-widget-title mh-related-content-title\">\n<span class=\"mh-widget-title-inner\">Related Articles</span></h3>\n<div class=\"mh-related-wrap mh-row clearfix\">\n<div class=\"mh-col-1-3 mh-posts-grid-col clearfix\">\n<article class=\"post-10648 format-standard mh-posts-grid-item clearfix\">\r\n\t<figure class=\"mh-posts-grid-thumb\">\r\n\t\t<a class=\"mh-thumb-icon mh-thumb-icon-small-mobile\" launch some CubeSats for free\t\t</a>\r\n\t</h3>\r\n\t<div class=\"mh-meta entry-meta\">\n<span class=\"entry-meta-date updated\"><i class=\"fa fa-clock-o\"></i><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/author/stephen-clark/\">Stephen Clark</a></span>\n</div>\n\t<div class=\"mh-posts-grid-excerpt clearfix\">\r\n\t\t<div class=\"mh-excerpt\"><p>United Launch Alliance chief executive Tory Bruno said Thursday the company will offer more rides for CubeSats aboard future Atlas 5 rocket flights, and give some away for free, in a bid to tap into a growing market of small satellites with applications in education, scientific research and commercial business. <a class=\"mh-excerpt-more\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2015/11/19/ula-says-it-will-launch-some-cubesats-for-free/\" title=\"ULA says it will launch some CubeSats for free\"></a></p>\n</div>\t</div>\r\n</article></div>\n<div class=\"mh-col-1-3 mh-posts-grid-col clearfix\">\n<article class=\"post-43614 format-standard mh-posts-grid-item clearfix\">\r\n\t<figure class=\"mh-posts-grid-thumb\">\r\n\t\t<a class=\"mh-thumb-icon mh-thumb-icon-small-mobile\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2020/02/14/antares-cygnus-ng-13-mission-status-center/\" title=\"Live coverage: Cygnus supply ship arrives at space station\t\t</a>\r\n\t</h3>\r\n\t<div class=\"mh-meta entry-meta\">\n<span class=\"entry-meta-date updated\"><i class=\"fa fa-clock-o\"></i><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2020/02/\">February 14, 2020</a></span>\n<span class=\"entry-meta-author author vcard\"><i class=\"fa fa-user\"></i><a class=\"fn\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/author/stephen-clark/\">Stephen Clark</a></span>\n</div>\n\t<div class=\"mh-posts-grid-excerpt clearfix\">\r\n\t\t<div class=\"mh-excerpt\"><p>Two-and-a-half days after launch from Virginia, a Northrop Grumman Cygnus supply ship arrived at the International Space Station Tuesday with nearly 7,500 pounds of cargo. Capture with the station&#8217;s robotic arm occurred at 4:05 a.m. EST (0905 GMT). <a class=\"mh-excerpt-more\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2020/02/14/antares-cygnus-ng-13-mission-status-center/\" title=\"Live coverage: Cygnus supply ship arrives at space station\"></a></p>\n</div>\t</div>\r\n</article></div>\n<div class=\"mh-col-1-3 mh-posts-grid-col clearfix\">\n<article class=\"post-6796 format-standard mh-posts-grid-item clearfix\">\r\n\t<figure class=\"mh-posts-grid-thumb\">\r\n\t\t<a class=\"mh-thumb-icon mh-thumb-icon-small-mobile\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2015/06/17/launch-campaign-underway-for-next-air-force-delta-4-rocket/\" title=\"Launch campaign underway for next Air Force Delta 4 rocket\"><img width=\"326\" height=\"245\" src=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/wgs_front-326x245.jpg\" class=\"attachment-mh-magazine-medium size-mh-magazine-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" srcset=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/wgs_front-326x245.jpg 326w, https://spaceflightnow.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/wgs_front-80x60.jpg 80w\" sizes=\"auto, (max-width: 326px) 100vw, 326px\" />\t\t</a>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"mh-image-caption mh-posts-grid-caption\">\r\n\t\t\t\tNews\t\t\t</div>\r\n\t\t\t</figure>\r\n\t<h3 class=\"entry-title mh-posts-grid-title\">\r\n\t\t<a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2015/06/17/launch-campaign-underway-for-next-air-force-delta-4-rocket/\" title=\"Launch campaign underway for next Air Force Delta 4 rocket\" rel=\"bookmark\">\r\n\t\t\tLaunch campaign underway for next Air Force Delta 4 rocket\t\t</a>\r\n\t</h3>\r\n\t<div class=\"mh-meta entry-meta\">\n<span class=\"entry-meta-date updated\"><i class=\"fa fa-clock-o\"></i><a href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2015/06/\">June 17, 2015</a></span>\n<span class=\"entry-meta-author author vcard\"><i class=\"fa fa-user\"></i><a class=\"fn\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/author/justin-sfn-ray/\">Justin Ray</a></span>\n</div>\n\t<div class=\"mh-posts-grid-excerpt clearfix\">\r\n\t\t<div class=\"mh-excerpt\"><p>With the Delta 4 rocket now waiting on the launch pad, its Air Force Wideband Global SATCOM communications satellite payload has jetted from the Los Angeles factory to the Cape Canaveral in preparation for liftoff this summer. <a class=\"mh-excerpt-more\" href=\"https://spaceflightnow.com/2015/06/17/launch-campaign-underway-for-next-air-force-delta-4-rocket/\" title=\"Launch campaign underway for next Air Force Delta 4 rocket\"></a></p>\n</div>\t</div>\r\n</article></div>\n</div>\n</section>\n<div id=\"comments\" class=\"mh-comments-wrap\">\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t<aside class=\"mh-widget-col-1 SpaceX’s most flown Falcon 9 rocket booster launched once again Saturday night, making its 33rd mission to space and back as the company works to certify its boosters for up to 40 flights each. The Starlink 6-104 mission added another 28 broadband internet satellites to SpaceX’s growing low Earth orbit constellation of more than 9,700 satellites. Liftoff from Space Launch Complex 40 (SLC-40) at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station happened at 10:47 p.m. EST (0347 UTC). The Falcon 9 rocket flew on a south-easterly trajectory upon leaving the pad. The 45th Weather Squadron forecast a greater than 95 percent chance for favorable weather during liftoff, citing no specific meteorological concerns. The 33rd flight of Falcon 9 booster 1067 came about 2.5 months after its previous launch in early December. Its previous missions include four flights for NASA, the European Commission’s Galileo L13, and 20 batches of Starlink satellites. Nearly 8.5 minutes after liftoff, B1067 landed on the droneship, ‘A Shortfall of Gravitas,’ positioned in the Atlantic Ocean. This was the 143rd landing on this vessel and the 575th booster landing to date for SpaceX.",

                          "source": "Spaceflight Now",
                          "content": "Engineers ran into problems repressurizing the Artemis 2 moon rocket’s upper stage helium tanks overnight Friday, a problem that will require rolling the huge rocket off the launch pad and back to its processing hangar for troubleshooting. The work will push the already delayed mission from March to at least early April, officials said Saturday. Pressurized helium is used to push propellants to rocket engines for ignition and to purge various fuel lines to clear them out before propellants flow. It’s not yet known what might be preventing helium to flow back into the SLS rocket’s upper stage following a successful countdown rehearsal test that ended Thursday. “Regardless of the potential fault, accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB (Vehicle Assembly Building),” NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman said in a post on the social media platform X. “We will begin preparations for rollback, and this will take the March launch window out of consideration.” As an update to my earlier post. – The ICPS helium bottles are used to purge the engines, as well as for LH2 and LOX tank pressurization. The systems did work correctly during WDR1 and WDR2. – Last evening, the team was unable to get helium flow through the vehicle. This… https://t.co/Qte3nEXwQb — NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman (@NASAAdmin) February 21, 2026 The Artemis 2 mission aims to send four astronauts – Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, Christina Koch and Canadian astronaut Jeremy Hansen – on a flight around the far side of the moon and back to thoroughly test the agency’s Orion deep space capsule to help clear the way for a lunar landing mission, Artemis 3, in 2028. Because of the ever-changing positions of the Earth and moon, and associated changes in lighting and other factors, only a handful of launch opportunities are available each month that meet the Artemis 2 mission requirements. The current launch period ends on March 11. The available launch dates next month are April 1, 3, 4, 5 and 6. Wiseman, Glover, Koch and Hansen originally hoped to launch early this month, but hydrogen leaks detected during an initial “wet dress countdown” rehearsal ultimately pushed the flight to March. NASA completed a second fueling test and countdown Thursday, loading the Space Launch System rocket with more than 750,000 gallons of liquid oxygen and hydrogen fuel while working through the steps that will be needed to actually launch the huge rocket on the long-awaited mission. The test went well, there were no fuel leaks like the ones that derailed plans for a launch earlier this month. Managers said Friday the team would press ahead for a launch attempt on March 6 to send Wiseman and his crewmates to the moon. Hoping for the best, the astronauts went into pre-flight medical quarantine at the Johnson Space Center Friday evening and planned to fly to the Kennedy Space Center on March 1 to prepare for launch. They now will leave quarantine to await developments. “I understand people are disappointed by this development,” Isaacman said. “That disappointment is felt most by the team at NASA, who have been working tirelessly to prepare for this great endeavor. During the 1960s, when NASA achieved what most thought was impossible, and what has never been repeated since, there were many setbacks. “There are many differences between the 1960s and today, and expectations should rightfully be high after the time and expense invested in this program. “I will say again, the President created Artemis as a program that will far surpass what America achieved during Apollo. We will return in the years ahead, we will build a Moon base, and undertake what should be continuous missions to and from the lunar environment. Where we begin with this architecture and flight rate is not where it will end.”",

                        "json": {
                          "title": "NASA prepares for likely rollback of SLS, delaying Artemis II to April",
                          "url": "https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2026/02/nasa-rollback-sls-delaying-artemis-april/",
                          "date": "February 21, 2026",
                          "thumbnail": "https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-33-45-477-wmarked.jpg",
                          "images": [
                            "https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1.jpg",
                            "https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916.jpg",
                            "https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276.jpg"
                          ],
                          "source": "NASASpaceFlight.com",
                          "content": "NASA is gearing up for a likely rollback of the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket and Orion spacecraft to the Vehicle Assembly Building (VAB) at Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The decision follows an unexpected interruption in helium flow within the rocket’s interim cryogenic propulsion stage (ICPS), observed overnight on Saturday, February 21, 2026. This issue with the ICPS has prompted teams to review data and prepare contingency measures, effectively ruling out the targeted March launch window and pushing the mission toward a possible April liftoff if the rollback is confirmed. Pre-rollback work is already underway, including the removal of pad access platforms installed yesterday. These platforms are subject to wind constraints and cannot be removed during high winds, which are forecasted for tomorrow. Following a successful second Wet Dress Rehearsal (WDR), NASA took the unusual step of announcing a target launch date of March 6 for Artemis II—despite traditionally waiting until the completion of the Flight Readiness Review (FRR) to set firm dates. Less than 24 hours later, that date became non-viable after an overnight helium flow anomaly was noted. Discover more NASA merchandise Chinese spaceflight analysis Space exploration books NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman addressed the development in a statement, emphasizing the troubleshooting efforts underway. “After overnight data showed an interruption in helium flow in the SLS interim cryogenic propulsion stage, teams are troubleshooting and preparing for a likely rollback of Artemis II to the VAB,” Isaacman said. “This will almost assuredly impact the March launch window.” Notably, NSF was hearing rumors of a potential vehicle issue that could result in a rollback on Saturday morning. Less than an hour later, NASA and Isaacman published a statement online—an impressive sign of the Administrator’s commitment to increasing transparency at the agency. The ICPS, or Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage, is effectively the SLS rocket’s upper stage. Derived from the Delta IV rocket’s second stage and adapted for Artemis missions, it uses liquid hydrogen (LH2) and liquid oxygen (LOX) as propellants to provide the necessary thrust after core stage burnout, enabling the Orion spacecraft to reach lunar orbit insertion trajectories. Helium plays a vital role in this system. Stored in onboard bottles, it purges the engines of residual gases and pressurizes the LH2 and LOX tanks during ascent. According to Isaacman, the ICPS helium system performed flawlessly during the first two Wet Dress Rehearsals (WDRs), which are full-scale fueling simulations conducted at Launch Pad 39B. The second WDR, in particular, proceeded according to plan with no indications of helium issues. “The ICPS helium bottles are used to purge the engines, as well as for LH2 and LOX tank pressurization. The systems did work correctly during WDR1 and WDR2,” he noted. The problem emerged during a routine repressurization operation last evening, catching teams off guard. “This was an unexpected development during routine helium flow operations last evening. The teams were up all night assessing the situation,” Isaacman added. Engineers are investigating potential causes, drawing parallels to a similar failure signature encountered during the Artemis I uncrewed mission in 2022. Possible faults include a final filter on the umbilical connection between ground systems and the vehicle, a failed quick-disconnect (QD) umbilical interface—where issues have been noted before—or a malfunctioning check valve onboard the rocket. Corrective measures were implemented post-Artemis I to reduce such risks for Artemis II, but the recurrence underscores the challenges of cryogenic systems in extreme environments. Isaacman also explained why a rollback is likely: remediation for any of these issues requires access only available in the VAB, which features numerous platform levels that rotate into place around the stack. “Regardless of the potential fault, accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB,” he confirmed. See Also Artemis Section L2 Artemis Click here to Join L2 The vehicle remains in a safe configuration, relying on ground-based environmental control systems (ECS) for engine purging instead of the onboard helium supply. This potential rollback echoes delays in previous Artemis preparations, where weather, technical glitches, and supply chain issues have repeatedly extended timelines. The March window, already tight, now appears off the table, with April emerging as the next viable opportunity—assuming swift resolution. “A rollback would mean NASA will not launch Artemis II in the March launch window,” NASA noted. “However, the quick preparations enable NASA to potentially preserve the April launch window if a rollback is required, pending the outcome of data findings, repair efforts, and how the schedule comes to fruition in the coming days and weeks.” NASA is set to provide another update during the coming week, which will also address requirements for a rollback, including resolution and return to the pad. The latter may require at least a tanking test or mini-WDR to confirm that the trip up and down the crawlerway did not affect systems such as the LH2 tail service mast umbilical (TSMU), which necessitated WDR2. Lead photo: Tyler Gray for NSF. 39B Artemis ICPS Orion SLS 0 Facebook Twitter Pinterest Email previous article Boeing insists NASA criticism will reinforce efforts on Starliner Related Articles 39A CAA removed, ending crew launch from historic...                           "raw_html_content": "\n\n\t\t\t\n\t\t\t<p>NASA is gearing up for a likely rollback of the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket and Orion spacecraft to the Vehicle Assembly Building (VAB) at Kennedy Space Center in Florida.</p>\n<p>The decision follows an unexpected interruption in helium flow within the rocket’s interim cryogenic propulsion stage (ICPS), observed overnight on Saturday, February 21, 2026.<br>\n</p>\n<p></p>\n<p>This issue with the ICPS has prompted teams to review data and prepare contingency measures, effectively ruling out the targeted March launch window and pushing the mission toward a possible April liftoff if the rollback is confirmed.</p>\n<p>Pre-rollback work is already underway, including the removal of pad access platforms installed yesterday. These platforms are subject to wind constraints and cannot be removed during high winds, which are forecasted for tomorrow.</p>\n<div class=\"twitter-tweet twitter-tweet-rendered\" style=\"display: flex; max-width: 550px; width: 100%; margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px;\"></div>\n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p>\n<p>Following a successful second Wet Dress Rehearsal (WDR), NASA took the unusual step of announcing a target launch date of March 6 for Artemis II—despite traditionally waiting until the completion of the Flight Readiness Review (FRR) to set firm dates.</p>\n<p>Less than 24 hours later, that date became non-viable after an overnight helium flow anomaly was noted.</p>\n<div><div class=\"penci-custom-html-inside-content\"><script async=\"\" src=\"https://pagead2.googlesyndication.com/pagead/js/adsbygoogle.js?client=ca-pub-2638787791243800\" crossorigin=\"anonymous\" data-checked-head=\"true\"></script>\n<ins class=\"adsbygoogle\" style=\"display: block; font-kerning: auto !important; font-optical-sizing: auto !important; font-size: inherit !important; font-stretch: 100% !important; font-style: normal !important; font-variant: normal !important; font-weight: inherit !important; outline: rgb(0, 0, 0) none 0px !important; outline-offset: 0px !important; overflow-anchor: auto !important; overflow-wrap: normal !important; overflow: visible !important; padding: 0px !important; pointer-events: auto !important; backface-visibility: visible !important; border-spacing: 0px !important; -webkit-border-image: none !important; -webkit-box-align: stretch !important; -webkit-box-decoration-break: slice !important; -webkit-box-direction: normal !important; -webkit-box-flex: 0 !important; -webkit-box-ordinal-group: 1 !important; -webkit-box-orient: horizontal !important; -webkit-box-pack: start !important; column-count: auto !important; gap: normal !important; column-rule: 0px rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; column-span: none !important; column-width: auto !important; backdrop-filter: none !important; place-content: normal !important; flex: 0 1 auto !important; flex-flow: row !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: auto !important; grid: none !important; grid-area: auto !important; hyphens: manual !important; hyphenate-character: auto !important; -webkit-line-break: auto !important; -webkit-line-clamp: none !important; -webkit-locale: auto !important; -webkit-mask-box-image-source: none !important; -webkit-mask-box-image-slice: 0 fill !important; -webkit-mask-box-image-width: auto !important; -webkit-mask-box-image-outset: 0px !important; -webkit-mask-box-image-repeat: stretch !important; mask: none !important; order: 0 !important; perspective: none !important; perspective-origin: 0px 0px !important; print-color-adjust: economy !important; -webkit-rtl-ordering: logical !important; shape-outside: none !important; shape-image-threshold: 0 !important; shape-margin: 0px !important; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4) !important; -webkit-text-combine: none !important; -webkit-text-decorations-in-effect: none !important; text-emphasis: none rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; text-emphasis-position: over right !important; -webkit-text-orientation: vertical-right !important; -webkit-text-security: none !important; -webkit-text-stroke: 0px rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; transform: none !important; transform-origin: 0px 0px !important; transform-style: flat !important; -webkit-user-drag: auto !important; -webkit-user-modify: read-only !important; user-select: auto !important; -webkit-writing-mode: horizontal-tb !important; app-region: none !important; buffered-rendering: auto !important; clip-path: none !important; clip-rule: nonzero !important; filter: none !important; flood-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; flood-opacity: 1 !important; lighting-color: rgb(255, 255, 255) !important; stop-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; stop-opacity: 1 !important; color-interpolation: srgb !important; color-interpolation-filters: linearrgb !important; color-rendering: auto !important; fill: rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; fill-opacity: 1 !important; fill-rule: nonzero !important; marker: none !important; mask-type: luminance !important; shape-rendering: auto !important; stroke: none !important; stroke-dasharray: none !important; stroke-dashoffset: 0px !important; stroke-linecap: butt !important; stroke-linejoin: miter !important; stroke-miterlimit: 4 !important; stroke-opacity: 1 !important; stroke-width: 1px !important; alignment-baseline: auto !important; baseline-shift: 0px !important; dominant-baseline: auto !important; text-anchor: start !important; writing-mode: inherit !important; vector-effect: none !important; paint-order: normal !important; d: none !important; cx: 0px !important; cy: 0px !important; x: 0px !important; y: 0px !important; r: 0px !important; rx: auto !important; ry: auto !important; caret-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) !important; line-break: auto !important; text-orientation: inherit !important;\"></div></div></div></div></ins>\n<script>\n     (adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({});\n</script></div></div><p>NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman addressed the development in a statement, emphasizing the troubleshooting efforts underway.</p>\n<p>“After overnight data showed an interruption in helium flow in the SLS interim cryogenic propulsion stage, teams are troubleshooting and preparing for a likely rollback of Artemis II to the VAB,” Isaacman said. “This will almost assuredly impact the March launch window.”</p>\n<p>Notably, NSF was hearing rumors of a potential vehicle issue that could result in a rollback on Saturday morning. Less than an hour later, NASA and Isaacman published a statement online—an impressive sign of the Administrator’s commitment to increasing transparency at the agency.</p>\n<div class=\"twitter-tweet twitter-tweet-rendered\" style=\"display: flex; max-width: 550px; width: 100%; margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px;\"></div>\n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p>\n<p>The ICPS, or Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage, is effectively the SLS rocket’s upper stage.</p>\n<p>Derived from the Delta IV rocket’s second stage and adapted for Artemis missions, it uses liquid hydrogen (LH2) and liquid oxygen (LOX) as propellants to provide the necessary thrust after core stage burnout, enabling the Orion spacecraft to reach lunar orbit insertion trajectories.<br>\n<img fetchpriority=\"high\" decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-112151\" src=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1170\" height=\"778\" srcset=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1.jpg 1170w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-350x233.jpg 350w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-526x350.jpg 526w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-768x511.jpg 768w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-585x390.jpg 585w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/KSC-20230815-PH-ULA01_0001large-1170x778-1-263x175.jpg 263w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1170px) 100vw, 1170px\">Helium plays a vital role in this system. Stored in onboard bottles, it purges the engines of residual gases and pressurizes the LH2 and LOX tanks during ascent.</p>\n<p>According to Isaacman, the ICPS helium system performed flawlessly during the first two Wet Dress Rehearsals (WDRs), which are full-scale fueling simulations conducted at Launch Pad 39B. The second WDR, in particular, proceeded according to plan with no indications of helium issues.</p>\n<p>“The ICPS helium bottles are used to purge the engines, as well as for LH2 and LOX tank pressurization. The systems did work correctly during WDR1 and WDR2,” he noted.</p>\n<p></p>\n<p>The problem emerged during a routine repressurization operation last evening, catching teams off guard.</p>\n<p>“This was an unexpected development during routine helium flow operations last evening. The teams were up all night assessing the situation,” Isaacman added.</p>\n<p>Engineers are investigating potential causes, drawing parallels to a similar failure signature encountered during the Artemis I uncrewed mission in 2022.</p>\n<p>Possible faults include a final filter on the umbilical connection between ground systems and the vehicle, a failed quick-disconnect (QD) umbilical interface—where issues have been noted before—or a malfunctioning check valve onboard the rocket.</p>\n<p>Corrective measures were implemented post-Artemis I to reduce such risks for Artemis II, but the recurrence underscores the challenges of cryogenic systems in extreme environments.</p>\n<p>Isaacman also explained why a rollback is likely: remediation for any of these issues requires access only available in the VAB, which features numerous platform levels that rotate into place around the stack.<br>\n<img decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-112152\" src=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1560\" height=\"885\" srcset=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916.jpg 1560w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-350x199.jpg 350w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-617x350.jpg 617w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-768x436.jpg 768w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-21-20-37-44-916-1170x664.jpg 1170w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1560px) 100vw, 1560px\">“Regardless of the potential fault, accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB,” he confirmed.</p>\n<aside class=\"penci-sidebar-content widget l2-info\"><h4 class=\"widget-title penci-border-arrow\"><span class=\"inner-arrow\">See Also</span></h4><ul><li><a href=\"https://forum.nasaspaceflight.com/index.php?board=48.0\">Artemis Section</a></li><li><a href=\"https://forum.nasaspaceflight.com/index.php?board=37.0\">L2 Artemis</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/l2/\">Click here to Join L2</a></li></ul></aside>\n<p>The vehicle remains in a safe configuration, relying on ground-based environmental control systems (ECS) for engine purging instead of the onboard helium supply.</p>\n<p>This potential rollback echoes delays in previous Artemis preparations, where weather, technical glitches, and supply chain issues have repeatedly extended timelines. The March window, already tight, now appears off the table, with April emerging as the next viable opportunity—assuming swift resolution.</p>\n<p>“A rollback would mean NASA will not launch Artemis II in the March launch window,” NASA noted. “However, the quick preparations enable NASA to potentially preserve the April launch window if a rollback is required, pending the outcome of data findings, repair efforts, and how the schedule comes to fruition in the coming days and weeks.”</p>\n<p>NASA is set to provide another update during the coming week, which will also address requirements for a rollback, including resolution and return to the pad.</p>\n<p>The latter may require at least a tanking test or mini-WDR to confirm that the trip up and down the crawlerway did not affect systems such as the LH2 tail service mast umbilical (TSMU), which necessitated WDR2.</p>\n<p><em>Lead photo: Tyler Gray for NSF.</em></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://shop.nasaspaceflight.com/pages/artemis-ii\"><img decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignnone wp-image-111837 size-full\" src=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1665\" height=\"891\" srcset=\"https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276.jpg 1665w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-350x187.jpg 350w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-630x337.jpg 630w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-768x411.jpg 768w, https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/NSF-2026-02-02-17-47-00-276-1170x626.jpg 1170w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1665px) 100vw, 1665px\"></a></p>\n\n\t\t\t\n            <div                         "json": {
                          "title": "German defense firm said to be weighing bid for Mynaric",
                          "url": "https://spacenews.com/german-defense-firm-said-to-be-weighing-bid-for-mynaric/",
                          "date": "February 22, 2026",
                          "thumbnail": "https://spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/FocqgZhaUAECh_z-scaled.jpeg",
                          "images": [],
                          "source": "SpaceNews",
                          "content": "WASHINGTON — Rheinmetall, Germany’s largest defense contractor, is weighing a potential acquisition of Munich-based laser communications terminal maker Mynaric, a move that could upend Rocket Lab’s previously announced plan to buy the company. German media first reported Rheinmetall’s interest, citing a desire to keep critical aerospace and laser communications technology under German and European control. Rheinmetall has not commented publicly. The reports come as Germany and other European nations intensify scrutiny of foreign takeovers involving sensitive defense technologies. Rocket Lab, the Long Beach, Calif.-based launch services provider and satellite manufacturer, said in March it planned to acquire Mynaric for roughly $150 million, subject to approval by German authorities under foreign direct investment rules. Nearly a year later, regulators have yet to sign off, and the deal has drawn heightened political attention as Europe accelerates efforts to build domestic space and defense capacity. The backdrop is Germany’s sharp increase in defense spending following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and growing uncertainty about long-term U.S. security commitments. Across Europe, governments are pairing higher defense budgets with industrial policies aimed at strengthening “sovereign” technological capabilities. Laser communications terminals fall squarely into that category. Mynaric develops optical terminals that transmit data between satellites using laser links, a technology viewed as essential for next-generation defense and commercial constellations. Compared with traditional radio-frequency systems, laser links can move data at higher rates and with greater resistance to interference, making them attractive for military networks. Subscribe Today Get unlimited access to SpaceNews.com and our digital magazine with a monthly, quarterly or annual subscription. Checkout Now Discounted Access Learn more about savings available for academic, government and military readers on SpaceNews subscriptions. Save on SpaceNews Mynaric’s CONDOR Mk3 optical terminal is designed for inter-satellite links and is already flying on spacecraft procured by the U.S. Space Development Agency for the Proliferated Warfighter Space Architecture, a planned constellation of low Earth orbit defense satellites intended to provide resilient communications and missile-tracking capabilities. For Rocket Lab, acquiring Mynaric would secure access to a critical subsystem and expand its footprint in Europe. The company has been building out its satellite manufacturing business alongside its launch operations and has positioned itself as an end-to-end provider of space services. Control over laser communications technology would reduce reliance on external suppliers for satellites destined for U.S. government and allied customers. Mynaric, for its part, has faced financial strains in recent years as it scaled production and worked through manufacturing setbacks. Despite those challenges, its technology has become strategically significant as Western governments push to deploy proliferated constellations in low Earth orbit.",
                          "raw_html_content": "<p>WASHINGTON — Rheinmetall, Germany’s largest defense contractor, is weighing a potential acquisition of Munich-based laser communications terminal maker Mynaric, a move that could upend Rocket Lab’s previously announced plan to buy the company.</p>\n\n<p><a href=\"https://www.welt.de/wirtschaft/article699846344f25149ec09b0512/mynaric-rheinmetall-erwaegt-uebernahme-von-deutschem-laser-spezialisten.html\">German media</a> first reported Rheinmetall’s interest, citing a desire to keep critical aerospace and laser communications technology under German and European control. Rheinmetall has not commented publicly. The reports come as Germany and other European nations intensify scrutiny of foreign takeovers involving sensitive defense technologies.</p>\n\n<p>Rocket Lab, the Long Beach, Calif.-based launch services provider and satellite manufacturer, said in March it planned to acquire Mynaric for roughly $150 million, subject to approval by German authorities under foreign direct investment rules. Nearly a year later, regulators have yet to sign off, and the deal has drawn heightened political attention as Europe accelerates efforts to build domestic space and defense capacity.</p>\n\n<p>The backdrop is Germany’s sharp increase in defense spending following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and growing uncertainty about long-term U.S. security commitments. Across Europe, governments are pairing higher defense budgets with industrial policies aimed at strengthening “sovereign” technological capabilities.</p>\n\n<p>Laser communications terminals fall squarely into that category. Mynaric develops optical terminals that transmit data between satellites using laser links, a technology viewed as essential for next-generation defense and commercial constellations. Compared with traditional radio-frequency systems, laser links can move data at higher rates and with greater resistance to interference, making them attractive for military networks.</p>\n<aside>\t\t\t<div\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tclass=\"newspack-popup-container newspack-popup hidden  newspack-inline-popup      \"\n\t\t\t\trole=\"button\"\n\t\t\t\ttabindex=\"0\"\n\t\t\t\tstyle=\"background-color:#a61c20;color:#fff\"\n\t\t\t\tid=\"id_556152\"\n\t\t\t\tdata-segments=\"13521\"\n\t\t\t\tdata-frequency=\"0,0,1,day\"\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t>\n\t\t\t\t\n<div class=\"wp-block-columns is-style-borders is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-9d6595d7 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex\">\n<div class=\"wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-center is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow\" style=\"flex-basis:50%\">\n<p class=\"has-text-align-left has-normal-font-size\"><strong>Subscribe Today</strong><br>Get unlimited access to SpaceNews.com and our digital magazine with a monthly, quarterly or annual subscription.</p>\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-newspack-blocks-checkout-button wp-block-button  \"><form data-checkout=\"{&quot;action_type&quot;:&quot;checkout_button&quot;,&quot;currency&quot;:&quot;USD&quot;,&quot;product_id&quot;:&quot;519854&quot;,&quot;product_type&quot;:&quot;membership&quot;,&quot;referrer&quot;:&quot;german-defense-firm-said-to-be-weighing-bid-for-mynaric&quot;,&quot;is_variable&quot;:true,&quot;variation_ids&quot;:[558699,519864,519865,519863]}\"><button class=\"wp-block-newspack-blocks-button wp-block-button__link     \" style=\"\" type=\"submit\">Checkout Now</button> <input type=\"hidden\" name=\"newspack_checkout\" value=\"1\" /><input type=\"hidden\" name=\"after_success_button_label\" value=\"Continue\" />\t\t\t<input\n\t\t\t\tname=\"newspack_popup_id\"\n\t\t\t\ttype=\"hidden\"\n\t\t\t\tvalue=\"556152\"\n\t\t\t/>\n\t\t\t<input\n\t\t\t\tname=\"prompt_title\"\n\t\t\t\ttype=\"hidden\"\n\t\t\t\tvalue=\"Subscribe to SpaceNews &#8211;                         "json": {
                          "title": "NASA preparing for Artemis 2 rollback to fix upper stage problem",
                          "url": "https://spacenews.com/nasa-preparing-for-artemis-2-rollback-to-fix-upper-stage-problem/",
                          "date": "February 21, 2026",
                          "thumbnail": "https://spacenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/art2-20260202.jpeg",
                          "images": [],
                          "source": "SpaceNews",
                          "content": "Updated 12:15 p.m. Eastern with additional comments from Isaacman. WASHINGTON — Just 24 hours after setting a March 6 launch date for the Artemis 2 mission, NASA announced Feb. 21 that a problem with the Space Launch System upper stage will delay the launch. In a brief statement , NASA said it was preparing to roll the SLS back from Launch Complex 39B at the Kennedy Space Center to the Vehicle Assembly Building after engineers found that helium flow in the rocket’s upper stage had been interrupted. Helium is used to pressurize tanks in the stage, formally known as the Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage. NASA had not reported any issues with helium flow or tank pressurization during a second wet dress rehearsal that concluded late Feb. 19. NASA initially said it had not yet made a final decision to roll the vehicle back to the Vehicle Assembly Building, or VAB, and was studying options to fix the problem at the pad as well as inside the VAB. However, in a social media post , NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman called a rollback “likely.” Subscribe Today Get unlimited access to SpaceNews.com and our digital magazine with a monthly, quarterly or annual subscription. Checkout Now Discounted Access Learn more about savings available for academic, government and military readers on SpaceNews subscriptions. Save on SpaceNews In a subsequent post , Isaacman said that while several potential causes for the problem, also seen during Artemis 1, were being considered, NASA would proceed with a rollback. \"Regardless of the potential fault, accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB,\" he stated. While studying repair options, workers began preparing for a potential rollback. That includes disassembling temporary work platforms that had just been installed at the launch pad for tasks such as retesting the rocket’s flight termination system. That work could not wait until Feb. 22, the agency said, because of high winds forecast that day. The announcement came a day after agency officials said at a briefing that they were working toward launching Artemis 2 as soon as March 6 , the first day of the next launch period for the mission. That opportunity runs through March 11. The upper stage problem and possible rollback “will almost assuredly impact the March launch window,” NASA said. Isaacman stated that the rollback \"will take the March launch window out of consideration.\" At the Feb. 20 briefing, NASA cautioned that work remained to prepare Artemis 2 for a March launch, including pad activities and a multiday flight readiness review. “But assuming that happens, it puts us in a very good position to target March 6,” said Lori Glaze, acting associate administrator for exploration systems development. “I’ve got a pretty high level of confidence in the configuration that we’re in right now,” added John Honeycutt, chair of NASA’s Artemis 2 mission management team. “It’s out there at the pad. It’s going to be there at the pad until we go fly.” If NASA is unable to launch Artemis 2 in March, the next launch window runs from April 1 to 6. Another window opens April 30, although NASA has not disclosed additional launch opportunities beyond the end of April. \"I understand people are disappointed by this development. That disappointment is felt most by the team at NASA, who have been working tirelessly to prepare for this great endeavor,\" Isaacman said, but noted there were \"many setbacks\" during the Apollo program before landing people on the moon in 1969.",
                          "raw_html_content": "<p><em>Updated 12:15 p.m. Eastern with additional comments from Isaacman.</em></p>\n\n<p>WASHINGTON — Just 24 hours after setting a March 6 launch date for the Artemis 2 mission, NASA announced Feb. 21 that a problem with the Space Launch System upper stage will delay the launch.</p>\n\n<p>In a brief <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/blogs/missions/2026/02/21/nasa-troubleshooting-artemis-ii-rocket-upper-stage-issue-preparing-to-roll-back/\">statement</a>, NASA said it was preparing to roll the SLS back from Launch Complex 39B at the Kennedy Space Center to the Vehicle Assembly Building after engineers found that helium flow in the rocket’s upper stage had been interrupted.</p>\n\n<p>Helium is used to pressurize tanks in the stage, formally known as the Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage. NASA had not reported any issues with helium flow or tank pressurization during a second wet dress rehearsal that concluded late Feb. 19.</p>\n\n<p>NASA initially said it had not yet made a final decision to roll the vehicle back to the Vehicle Assembly Building, or VAB, and was studying options to fix the problem at the pad as well as inside the VAB. It’s going to be there at the pad until we go fly.”</p>\n\n<p>If NASA is unable to launch Artemis 2 in March, the next launch window runs from April 1 to 6. Another window opens April 30, although NASA has not disclosed additional launch opportunities beyond the end of April.</p>\n\n<p>&#8220;I understand people are disappointed by this development.                           "title": "SpaceX’s most-flown Falcon booster launches on record 33rd flight",
                          "url": "https://spaceflightnow.com/2026/02/21/live-coverage-spacexs-most-flown-falcon-booster-to-launch-on-record-33rd-flight/",

                          "source": "Spaceflight Now",
                          "content": "Update Feb. 21, 12 a.m. EST (0500 UTC): SpaceX confirms satellite deployment. SpaceX’s most flown Falcon 9 rocket booster launched once again Saturday night, making its 33rd mission to space and back as the company works to certify its boosters for up to 40 flights each. The Starlink 6-104 mission added another 28 broadband internet satellites to SpaceX’s growing low Earth orbit constellation of more than 9,700 satellites. Liftoff from Space Launch Complex 40 (SLC-40) at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station happened at 10:47 p.m. EST (0347 UTC). The Falcon 9 rocket flew on a south-easterly trajectory upon leaving the pad. The 45th Weather Squadron forecast a greater than 95 percent chance for favorable weather during liftoff, citing no specific meteorological concerns. The 33rd flight of Falcon 9 booster 1067 came about 2.5 months after its previous launch in early December. Its previous missions include four flights for NASA, the European Commission’s Galileo L13, and 20 batches of Starlink satellites. Nearly 8.5 minutes after liftoff, B1067 landed on the droneship, ‘A Shortfall of Gravitas,’ positioned in the Atlantic Ocean. This was the 143rd landing on this vessel and the 575th booster landing to date for SpaceX.",

The Falcon 9 rocket flew on a south-easterly trajectory upon leaving the pad.</p>\n<p><iframe title=\"YouTube video player\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/r2t9aB0pemM?si=dUiTySbeJbuhto1H\" width=\"678\" height=\"381\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"><span data-mce-type=\"bookmark\" style=\"display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;\" class=\"mce_SELRES_start\">﻿</span></iframe></p>\n<p>The 45th Weather Squadron forecast a greater than 95 percent chance for favorable weather during liftoff, citing no specific meteorological concerns.</p>\n<p>The 33rd flight of Falcon 9 booster 1067 came about 2.5 months after its previous launch in early December.
